

 ****** List of adult alternative artists

b"{{multiple issues|
{{Orphan|date=January 2015}}
{{Refimprove|date=January 2010}}
}}

The following lists bands or artists that are played on [[adult album alternative]] radio stations, or have been cited as part of the ''adult alternative pop/rock'' music genre.
{{Compact ToC|num=no|side=yes|center=yes|nobreak=yes}}
{{multicol}}

[[Category:Alternative country musicians| ]]
[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Alternative country musicians]]'

 ****** List of ambient music artists

b'{{pp-semi-indef}}This is a list of [[ambient music]] artists. This includes artists who have either been very important to the genre or have had a considerable amount of exposure (such as in the case of one that has been on a major label, but not limited to such). This list does not include little-known local artists. Artists are listed by the first letter in their name (not including the words "a", "an", or "the"), and individuals are listed by last name.

{{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}

{{Col-begin}}
{{Col-break}}

 ****** List of big band musicians

b'* [[Andy Kirk (musician)|Andy Kirk]] (1898&ndash;1992)<ref>[http://books.google.es/books?id=FK50ScZXeIoC&pg=PA71&lpg=PA71&dq=%22Reuben+Phillips%22+AND+sax&source=bl&ots=-qzLYVEg-r&sig=g055r_ms11gUtv0d3Xx8qDLy-z0&hl=es&ei=_DyJSoL_GuOZjAfG-PiiCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10#v=onepage&q=&f=false Evans, Joe and Brooks, Christopher \'\'Follow your heart: moving with the giants of jazz, swing, and rhythm and blues\'\'. University of Illinois Press, 2008 ISBN 0-252-03303-5, ISBN 978-0-252-03303-2] [[Joe Evans (musician)|Joe Evans]] autobiography at Google Books</ref>
* [[Bix Beiderbecke]] (1903&ndash;1931)<ref>Williams acknowledges that "Young himself gave most of the credit to [Frankie] Trumbauer \xe2\x80\xa6 but I doubt if a man who carried \'\'Singin\' the Blues\'\' around in his tenor case was unaffected by Bix\'s part in it" (p. 69).</ref>
* [[Buster Bailey]] (1902&ndash;1967)<ref>Kernfeld, Barry, ed. \'\'The New Gove Dictionary of Jazz\'\', vol. 1. London: Macmillan Publishers, Ltd., 2002.</ref>
* [[Chick Webb]] (1905&ndash;1939)<ref name="Smith">[http://www.tomsmithbigband.com/swing-music-history.html "Swing Music History"], last accessed Jan 12, 2010</ref>
* [[Count Basie]] (1904&ndash;1984)<ref>Count Basie, 1985, p. 51</ref>
* [[Dizzy Gillespie]]  (1917\xe2\x80\x931993)<ref>Watrous, P. [http://www.nytimes.com/learning/general/onthisday/bday/1021.html?scp=9&sq=George%20Russell%20composer&st=cse Dizzy Gillespie, Who Sounded Some of Modern Jazz\'s Earliest Notes, Dies at 75], \'\'[[NY Times]]\'\' Obituary, January 7, 1993</ref>
* [[Duke Ellington]] (1899&ndash;1974)<ref>Pulitzer Prize Winners Special Awards and Citations [http://www.pulitzer.org/citation/1999-Special-Awards-and-Citations 1999 Pulitzer Prize Winners Special Awards and Citations]</ref>
* [[Eddie Lang]] (1902&ndash;1933)
* [[George Paxton]] (1914&ndash;1989)
* [[Chico Freeman]] (1949&ndash;)
* [[Jimmy Dorsey]] (1904&ndash;1957)
* [[Joe Venuti]] (1903&ndash;1978)
* [[Les Brown (bandleader)|Les Brown]] (1912\xe2\x80\x932001)
* [[Lionel Hampton]] (1908&ndash;2002)
* [[Ray Anthony]] (1922&ndash;)
* [[Teddy Wilson]] (1912&ndash;1986)
* [[Xavier Cugat]] (1900&ndash;1990)
* [[Wynton Marsalis]] (1961&ndash;)

[[Category:Black metal]]
[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Black metal]]


 ****** List of black metal bands, L-Z

{{lead too short|date=November 2011}}
This is a '''list of black metal bands''' (letters L through Z) including bands that have at some point in their careers played black metal.

 ****** List of blue-eyed soul artists

b'This is a list of notable [[blue-eyed soul]] artists. Blue-eyed soul (also known as white soul) is [[soul music]] or [[rhythm and blues]] performed by white artists.<ref name="Blue-Eyed Soul">{{cite web|url= http://www.allmusic.com/style/blue-eyed-soul-ma0000012036 |title= R&B \xc2\xbb Soul \xc2\xbb Blue-Eyed Soul |publisher= [[AllMusic]]. [[All Media Network]] |accessdate= 9 March 2014}}</ref>

{{Compact ToC|center=yes}}

==A==
{{div col|colwidth=30em}}
*[[Adele]]<ref name="EMM">Cairns, Dan (1 February 2009). {{Wayback|date= 20110616203103 |title= Blue-eyed soul: Encyclopedia of Modern Music |url= http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article5597699.ece |df= yes}}. \'\'[[The Sunday Times]]\'\'. Retrieved 9 March 2014.</ref>
*[[Christina Aguilera]]<ref name="New">{{cite news|first= A.D. |last= Amorosi |title= A new blue-eyed soul man in town |newspaper= [[The Philadelphia Inquirer|The Inquirer]] |url= http://articles.philly.com/2007-03-18/entertainment/25237103_1_robin-thicke-blue-eyed-soul-silk-degrees |publisher= [[Philadelphia Media Network|Philly.com]] |date= 18 March 2007 |accessdate= 9 March 2014}}</ref>
*[[Anastacia]]<ref>{{cite news|first= Mike |last= Zwerin |title= A Few Good Sounds for Summer |newspaper= [[The New York Times]] |url= http://www.nytimes.com/2000/07/05/style/05iht-records.t.html |quote= Anastacia is a young blue-eyed soul singer and songwriter of some poise and considerable promise from New York. |date= 5 July 2000 |accessdate= 9 March 2014}}</ref>
*[[The Animals]]<ref name="pc52">{{Gilliland|url= http://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc19834/m1/ |title= Show 52 - The Soul Reformation: Phase three, soul music at the summit. [Part 8] |show= 52}}</ref>
*[[Rick Astley]]<ref name="Bieber">{{cite news|first= Tris |last= McCall |title= Justin Bieber concert: The kid connected at the Prudential Center |url= http://www.nj.com/entertainment/music/index.ssf/2010/08/justin_bieber_concert_the_kid.html |publisher= [[NJ.com]] |newspaper= [[The Star-Ledger]] |quote= But for the most part, Bieber\xe2\x80\x99s pop is a throwback to the machine-pressed blue-eyed soul of the DayGlo decade: George Michael, Paul Young, Hall and Oates at their most optimistic, and especially Rick Astley. |date= 30 August 2010 |accessdate= 28 May 2014}}</ref>
*[[Atlanta Rhythm Section]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Atlanta Rhythm Section |url= http://www.virginmedia.com/music/browse/atlanta-rhythm-section/ |publisher= [[Virgin Media]] |accessdate= 21 June 2014}}</ref>
*[[Atomic Rooster]]{{sfn|Larkin|2011|loc="Atomic Rooster"|ps=: A dramatic musical shift towards blue-eyed soul won few new fans, however, and [Vincent] Crane finally dissolved the band in 1974.}}

[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Blue-eyed soul]]'

 ****** List of blues musicians

b'{{unreferenced|date=January 2013}}
{{use mdy dates|date=January 2013}}

Performers in the [[blues]] style range from primitive, one-chord Delta players to [[big band]]s to [[country music]] to [[rock and roll]] to [[classical music]].

{{dynamic list|date=January 2013}}

{{blues|state=collapsed}}

[[Category:Lists of blues musicians| ]]
[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Blues]]'

 ****** List of blues rock musicians

b'<!-- Note: Do not add just any artist that generally falls into the genre; please only add well-known artists of whose pieces most are representative of the genre (i.e. the majority of their songs are considered blues rock). It is recommended that to discuss any proposed changes to the list on the talk page first, as the list should really not grow much lengthier. -->
<!-- Please only put bands here that already have a Wikipedia article. If the band does not have a Wikipedia article, please create one. If the band is not notable enough to warrant a Wiki article, then they should not be in this list article either.... despite popular misconceptions, list articles are required to have references, just like a regular article. Thanks. -->
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}}
The following is a list of [[blues rock]] musicians.

Blues rock is a subgenre of [[Rock music|rock]] which developed in the late-1960s and which emphasizes the traditional, [[Three-chord song|three-chord blues song]] and instrumental [[Musical improvisation|improvisation]]. The first original blues rock artists such as [[Cream (band)|Cream]], the [[Paul Butterfield|Paul Butterfield Blues Band]] and [[Canned Heat]] actually borrowed the idea of combining an instrumental combo with loud [[Amplifier|amplification]] from [[rock and roll]], and also attempted to play long, involved improvisations which were commonplace on jazz records and live blues shows. As blues rock gained popularity, bands that followed immediately were louder and more [[riff]]-oriented, giving birth to both [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] and [[Southern rock]], which both used basic blues riffs and featured extended [[Solo (music)|solos]]. In the early 1970s, the lines between blues rock and [[hard rock]] were barely visible, as bands including [[ZZ Top]] began recording rock-oriented [[Studio album|albums]] that tended to obscure their [[blues]] roots. However, blues rock soon distinguished itself from hard rock and acts continued to play or rewrite [[List of blues standards|blues standards]], as well as write their own songs in the same idiom. In the 1980s and 1990s, blues rock was more roots-oriented than in the 1960s and 1970s, even when artists such as [[the Fabulous Thunderbirds]] and [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]] flirted with rock stardom.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.allmusic.com/style/blues-rock-ma0000002468 |title= Pop/Rock \xc2\xbb Rock & Roll/Roots \xc2\xbb Blues-Rock |publisher= [[AllMusic]]. [[All Media Network]] |accessdate= 21 November 2013}}</ref>

Solo artists are listed alphabetically by last name, and groups are listed alphabetically by the first letter (not including the prefix "the", "a" or "an").

*[[Them (band)|Them]]<ref>{{cite web|title= Van Morrison Biography |url= http://rockhall.com/inductees/van-morrison/bio/ |publisher= The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum |accessdate= 19 September 2014}}</ref>
*[[George Thorogood]]{{sfn|Du Noyer|2003|p=181}}{{sfn|Adelt|2010|p=136}}
*[[Pat Travers]]{{sfn|Prown|Newquist|1997|p=172}}<ref>{{cite web|first= Alex |last= Henderson |title= Pat Travers \xe2\x80\x93 Travelin\' Blues |publisher= AllMusic. All Media Network |url= http://www.allmusic.com/album/travelin-blues-mw0000819361 |accessdate= 13 September 2014}}</ref>
*[[Treat Her Right]]{{sfn|Talevski|2006|p=571}}
*[[Triggerfinger]]<ref>{{cite journal|title= Triggerfinger, le doigt sur la d\xc3\xa9tente |magazine= [[Rolling Stone#International editions|Rolling Stone Magazine France]] |publisher= 1633 |first= Sophie |last= Rosemont |url= http://www.rollingstone.fr/triggerfinger-doigt-detente/ |date= 24 May 2014 |accessdate= 19 September 2014 |language= fr}}</ref>
*[[Walter Trout]]{{sfn|Adelt|2010|p=137|ps=: Vaughan\'s short career and highly publicized death in a plane crash in 1990 accelerated the careers of a number of white blues-rock guitarists like Walter Trout and Joe Bonamassa.}}{{sfn|Williamson|2007|p=348}}
*[[Robin Trower]]<ref>{{cite web|first= Bret |last= Adams |title= Robin Trower \xe2\x80\x93 Passion |url= http://www.allmusic.com/album/passion-mw0000650905 |publisher= AllMusic. All Media Network |accessdate= 13 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Robin Trower\'s Blues-Rock Power |publisher= NPR Music |url= http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=89727088 |date= 17 April 2008 |accessdate= 13 September 2014}}</ref>
*[[Derek Trucks]]<ref>{{cite web|first= Richard |last= Skelly |title= Derek Trucks \xe2\x80\x93 Artist Biography |publisher= AllMusic. All Media Network |url= http://www.allmusic.com/artist/derek-trucks-mn0000202162/biography |accessdate= 1 November 2013}}</ref>
*[[Duke Tumatoe]]<ref>{{cite news|first= Steve |last= Hochman |newspaper= Los Angeles Times |date= 3 June 1989 |url= http://articles.latimes.com/1989-06-03/entertainment/ca-754_1_pop-beat-palomino-band |title= POP BEAT : Ripe Tumatoe and Band at Palomino |accessdate= 16 September 2014}}</ref>
{{div col end}}

*[[Javier Vargas (musician)|Javier Vargas]]<ref>{{cite news|first= Jos\xc3\xa9 |last= M\xc2\xaa Mart\xc3\xadn |newspaper= [[20 minutos]] |date= 5 November 2008 |url= http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/426153/0/entrevista/javier/vargas/ |title= Javier Vargas, de la Vargas Blues Band: "La m\xc3\xbasica es gratis; yo cobro s\xc3\xb3lo por el viaje" |accessdate= 19 September 2014 |language= es}}</ref>
*[[Jimmie Vaughan]]<ref name="Burr"/>{{sfn|Prown|Newquist|1997|p=219}}
*[[Stevie Ray Vaughan]]{{sfn|Daume|1993|p=69}}{{sfn|Komara|2006|p=204}}{{sfn|Milward|2013|p=189}}{{sfn|Prown|Newquist|1997|p=217}}{{sfn|Unterberger|1999|p=348}}

==W==

*[[Warumpi Band]]<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.allmusic.com/artist/warumpi-band-mn0000631119/biography |first= Curtis |last= Zimmermann |title= Warumpi Band \xe2\x80\x93 Artist Biography |publisher= AllMusic. All Media Network |accessdate= 9 September 2014}}</ref>
*[[Jack White]]<ref>{{cite news|title= Jack White \xe2\x80\x93 Blunderbuss |work= Atlanta Music |publisher= State.ie |first= Terence |last= Caron |date= 4 May 2012 |url= http://www.state.ie/album-reviews/jack-white-blunderbuss |accessdate= 1 November 2013}}</ref>

[[Viacom]] |title= White Stripes Meet The Coal Miner\xe2\x80\x99s Daughter At New York Show |url= http://www.mtv.com/news/1471389/white-stripes-meet-the-coal-miners-daughter-at-new-york-show/ |date= 21 April 2003 |accessdate= 9 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title= This is Pop: in Search of the Elusive at Experience Music Project |first= Eric |last= Weisbard |publisher= [[Harvard University Press]] |year= 2004 |isbn= 0-674-01321-2 |page= 105}}</ref>

*[[David Wilcox (Canadian musician)|David Wilcox]]<ref>{{cite web|first= Charlotte |last= Dillon |title= David Wilcox \xe2\x80\x93 Artist Biography |publisher= AllMusic. All Media Network |url= http://www.allmusic.com/artist/david-wilcox-mn0000228850/biography |quote= After a few years, Wilcox decided to move on and formed a band called the Teddybears, before trying his luck at performing solo, doing both blues-rock and roots rock at the time. |accessdate= 14 November 2013}}</ref>
*[[Edgar Winter]]<ref name="Burr"/>
*[[Johnny Winter]]<ref name="Burr"/>{{sfn|Prown|Newquist|1997|pp=37, 40}}{{sfn|Larkin|2011|loc="Lazy Lester"}}{{sfn|Whitburn|2009|p=280}}

*[[Wishbone Ash]]<ref>{{cite book|title= Is This the Real Life?: The Untold Story of Queen |quote= Previously Queen had supported Wishbone Ash, the denizens of progressive blues-rock, notable for having two lead guitarists. |publisher= [[Da Capo Press]] |first= Mark |last= Blake |authorlink= Mark Blake (writer) |year= 2011 |isbn= 978-0-306-81959-9 |page= 111}}</ref>
*[[Ronnie Wood]]<ref>{{cite news|first= Alexis |last= Petridis |newspaper= The Guardian |title= Ronnie Wood \xe2\x80\x93 review |date= 20 October 2010 |url= http://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/oct/20/ronnie-wood-review |accessdate= 13 September 2014}}</ref>

 ****** List of boogie woogie musicians

b'{{Unreferenced|date=October 2010}}
Among the many [[boogie-woogie]] musicians are not only [[blues]] players,{{citation needed|date=July 2007}} but [[rock and roll]], and [[country music]]ians as well, and at least one [[european classical music|classical musician]].

Musicians noted for playing boogie-woogie (many of whom also perform in other styles):

==A==
*[[Rob Agerbeek]] (born 1937), [[Indonesia]]n-born [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[boogie-woogie]] and early [[jazz]] pianist
*[[Albert Ammons]], (1907\xe2\x80\x931949), American pianist, father of [[bebop]] [[saxophone|tenorman]] [[Gene Ammons]]
*[[Andrews Sisters]], American singers known for "[[Beat Me Daddy, Eight to the Bar]]" and "[[Boogie-woogie Bugle Boy]]"
*[[Winifred Atwell]] (1914\xe2\x80\x931983) British pianist, from Trinidad

==B==
*[[Bob Baldori]] (born 1943), aka "Boogie Bob", American [[Rock music|rock]], [[blues]], and boogie-woogie [[musician]]
*[[Marcia Ball]] (born 1949), American singer and pianist
*[[Deanna Bogart]], (born 1960), American singer, pianist, and saxophonist
*[[James Booker]] (1939\xe2\x80\x931983), American pianist
*[[Eden Brent]] (born 1965), American pianist and vocalist

==C==
*[[Commander Cody and His Lost Planet Airmen]], known for "[[Beat Me Daddy, Eight to the Bar]]"
*[[Francis Craig]]  (1900-1966) "[[Near You]]"
*[[James Crutchfield]] (1912-2001) St. Louis Barrelhouse Blues

==D==
*[[Caroline Dahl]], pianist and composer of boogie-woogie and American roots music
*[[Cow Cow Davenport]] (1894\xe2\x80\x931945), American pianist
*[[Blind John Davis]] (1913\xe2\x80\x931985), American pianist and singer
*[[Wendy DeWitt]] American pianist, composer, vocalist <ref>http://www.allmusic.com/artist/wendy-dewitt-mn0002304459</ref>
*[[Neville Dickie]] (born 1937), English pianist
*[[Dorothy Donegan]] (1922\xe2\x80\x931998). American pianist
*[[Georgia Tom Dorsey]] (1899\xe2\x80\x931993), American pianist and gospel songwriter
*[[Dr. John]] (born 1940), New Orleans blues and boogie woogie pianist and composer of "Boxcar Boogie" among others
*[[Champion Jack Dupree]] (1908\xe2\x80\x931992), [[New Orleans blues]] player
*[[Big Joe Duskin]] (1921\xe2\x80\x932007), American pianist

==E==
*[[William Ezell]] (1892\xe2\x80\x931963), Texas-born pianist who combined boogie-woogie with [[ragtime]] and [[blues]]

==F==
*[[Fats Domino]], (born 1928), American R&B pianist and singer who recorded some boogie pieces in the 1950s
*[[Wayne Federman]] (born 1959), originated "Liver Lips Boogie"
*[[Ella Fitzgerald]] with [[The Ink Spots]] covered "Cow Cow Boogie".
*[[Frankie Ford]] (born 1939), who performed "[[Sea Cruise]]" with [[Huey Piano Smith|Huey "Piano" Smith]] accompanying on the piano
*[[Floyd Domino]], American musician
*[[Ernie Freeman]] (1922\xe2\x80\x931981), American pianist, organist, and arranger

==G==
*[[Harry Gibson]] "The Hipster" (1915\xe2\x80\x931991)
*[[Henry Gray (musician)|Henry Gray]] (born 1925), American pianist credited with helping to create the Chicago blues piano sound

==H==
*[[Willie Hall (pianist)|Willie Hall]], known as Drive\'em Down, model and mentor to many New Orleans players
*[[Jools Holland]], (born 1958) British musician and television presenter
*[[Camille Howard]] (1914\xe2\x80\x931993), American pianist and singer
*[[Bob Hall (musician)|Bob Hall]] (born 1942), English pianist
*[[Jim Jones Revue|Henri Herbert]] , English pianist, member of The Jim Jones Revue

==J==
*[[Pete Johnson]], (1904\xe2\x80\x931967) Big Joe Turner\'s piano partner; "[[Roll \'Em Pete]]" was named for him

==K==
*[[Michael Kaeshammer]], (born 1977 or 1978), a Canadian pianist, vocalist, and arranger
*[[Shizuko Kasagi]] (1914\xe2\x80\x931985), Japanese singer known in Japan as the {{nihongo|\'\'"Queen of the Boogie-Woogie"\'\'|\xe3\x83\x96\xe3\x82\xae\xe3\x81\xae\xe5\xa5\xb3\xe7\x8e\x8b|Bugi no oj\xc5\x8d}}.
*[[Joe Krown]], a blues/R&B pianist/organist based in New Orleans

==L==
*[[Booker T. Laury]] (1914\xe2\x80\x931995), American pianist and singer
*[[Jerry Lee Lewis]] (born 1935), American pianist, singer, and songwriter
*[[Meade Lux Lewis]] (1905\xe2\x80\x931964), American pianist whose "[[Honky Tonk Train Blues]]" was an early boogie woogie hit
*[[Liberace]] (1919\xe2\x80\x931987), American pianist
*[[Little Richard]] (born 1932), American pianist, singer, and songwriter
*[[Little Willie Littlefield]] (1931-2013), American pianist and singer
*[[Cripple Clarence Lofton]] (1887-1957)

==M==
*[[Memphis Slim]] (1915\xe2\x80\x931988)
*[[Big Maceo Merriweather]] (1905\xe2\x80\x931953), composer of "Chicago Breakdown"

==N==
*[[Romeo Nelson]] (1902\xe2\x80\x931974)
*[[Charlie Norman]] (1920\xe2\x80\x932005), Swedish piano player

==P==
*[[Bill Payne]] (born 1949), piano player for [[Little Feat]]
*[[Oscar Peterson]], (1925\xe2\x80\x932007), modern jazz player, performed duo piano version of "Honky Tonk Train Blues" with [[Keith Emerson]]
*[[Piano Red]] (1911\xe2\x80\x931985), brother of [[Speckled Red]]
*[[Pinetop Perkins]] (1913\xe2\x80\x932011), American musician and teacher of [[Ike Turner]]
*[[Ross Petot]], American pianist
*[[Sammy Price]] (1908\xe2\x80\x931992), American pianist and bandleader
*[[Professor Longhair]], (Henry "Roy" Byrd, 1918\xe2\x80\x931980), American singer and pianist

==R==
*[[Boogie Woogie Red]] (1925&ndash;1985) American pianist, frequent collaborator with [[John Lee Hooker]]
*[[Maurice Rocco]] (died 1976), American pianist, singer, and actor
*[[Walter Roland]] (c. 1903\xe2\x80\x931972), American pianist, guitarist, and singer
*[[Leon Russell]] (born 1942), American musician and songwriter

==S==
*[[Ulf Sandstr\xc3\xb6m (pianist)|Ulf Sandstr\xc3\xb6m]] (born 1964), Swedish pianist and member of jump4joy
*[[Bob Seeley]] (born c. 1930), American pianist
*[[Luca Sestak]] born 1995), German Boogie-Woogie, Blues and Jazz pianist.
*[[Omar Shariff]] (stage name of Dave Alexander, 1938\xe2\x80\x932012), American singer and pianist
*[[Robert Shaw (blues musician)|Robert Shaw]] (1908\xe2\x80\x931985), American barrelhouse pianist, recorded "The Ma Grinder"
*[[Freddie Slack]] (1910\xe2\x80\x931965), American pianist and bandleader, originator of "Beat Me Daddy, Eight To The Bar" in the 1940s
*[[Huey Piano Smith|Huey "Piano" Smith]] (born 1934), "Rockin\' Pneumonia and the Boogie Woogie Flu", also accompanist on [[Frankie Ford]]\'s "[[Sea Cruise]]"
*[[Pinetop Smith|Clarence "Pine Top" Smith]] (1904\xe2\x80\x931929), "Pine Top\'s Boogie Woogie" in 1929 was the first boogie-woogie hit and popularized the name for the style
*[[Charlie Spand]] (unknown)
*[[Otis Spann]], (1930\xe2\x80\x931970), Delta blues and boogie player, toured solo and with [[Muddy Waters]]
*[[Speckled Red]] (1892\xe2\x80\x931973), American pianist and singer, recorded "The Dirty Dozens"
*[[Roosevelt Sykes]] (1906\xe2\x80\x931983), American pianist

==T==
*[[Gene Taylor (pianist)|Gene Taylor]] (born 1952), American pianist who has played with Canned Heat, Blasters, Fried Bourbon
*[[Montana Taylor]] (1902\xe2\x80\x931974), American pianist
*[[George W. Thomas]] (1885\xe2\x80\x93c.1930), American pianist and songwriter
*[[Hersal Thomas]] (c.1909\xe2\x80\x931926), American pianist and composer
*[[Stephanie Trick]] (born 1987), American boogie-woogie, stride, ragtime and jazz pianist 
*[[Big Joe Turner]], (1911\xe2\x80\x931985), American boogie-woogie singer, partnered with Pete Johnson
*[[Ike Turner]], (1931\xe2\x80\x932007), American musician, bandleader, and [[record producer]]

==W==
*[[Tuts Washington]] (1907\xe2\x80\x931984), mentor to many generations of [[New Orleans]] pianists
*[[Kenny "Blues Boss" Wayne]] (born 1944), American-born boogie-woogie/blues/R&B pianist
*[[Vince Weber]] (born 1953), German boogie/blues musician
*[[Robert Wells (composer)|Robert Wells]], Swedish pianist, singer, and composer
*[[Clarence Williams (musician)|Clarence Williams]] (1898\xe2\x80\x931965), American pianist and composer who recorded some of the first examples of boogie-woogie
*[[Jabo Williams]], American pianist and songwriter
*[[Mitch Woods]] (born 1951), American modern day boogie-woogie, [[jazz]] and [[jump blues]] pianist

==Y==
*[[Jimmy Yancey]] (1898\xe2\x80\x931951), American pianist, composer, and lyricist

==Z==
*[[Silvan Zingg]] (born 1973), Swiss pianist
*[[Axel Zwingenberger]] (born 1955), German pianist and composer

==Additional note==
Meade Lux Lewis, Albert Ammons, and Pete Johnson sometimes played together by twos or threes, an unusual practice.  See [[Boogie-woogie]] for more information.

 ****** List of breakcore artists

b'<!-- Note: Wikipedia is not a repository for links. Do not add URLs here. --> 
<!-- ONLY add artists that have their own Wikipedia page -->
This is a list of notable [[breakcore]] artists. This includes artists who have either been very influential within the genre, or are nationally known due to a considerable amount of exposure (for example, an artist that has released material on a major record label). This list does not include artists whose notability is restricted to their local scene or home country. Artists are listed by the first letter in their name (not including the words "a", "an", or "the"), and individuals are listed by last name.

{{colbegin||20em}}
*[[Bong-Ra]]
*[[Deformer]]
*[[DJ Balli]]
*[[Doormouse]]
*[[Droon]]
*[[Edgey]]
*[[Eiterherd]]
*[[Alec Empire]]
*[[Enduser (artist)|Enduser]]
*[[Eustachian (band)|Eustachian]]
*[[Fanny (artist)|Fanny]]
*[[Jason Forrest]] (Donna Summer or DJ Donna Summer)
*[[Praxis Records|Christoph Fringeli]]
*[[Hecate (musician)|Hecate]]
*[[Hypnoskull]]
*[[Iszoloscope]]
*[[Igorrr]]
*[[Benn Jordan]]
*[[Kettel]]
*[[Kid606]]
*[[Knifehandchop]]
*[[Ladyscraper]]
*[[Istari Lasterfahrer]]
*[[Nasenbluten]]
*[[Nero\'s Day At Disneyland]]
*[[Ove-Naxx]]
*[[Phallus \xc3\x9cber Alles]]
*[[Phuq]]
*[[Shitmat]]
*[[Sickboy Milkplus]]
*[[Shizuo]]
*[[Satanicpornocultshop]]
*[[Terminal 11]]
*[[Venetian Snares]]
*[[Otto Von Schirach]]
*[[Wisp (musician)|Wisp]]
*[[Xanopticon]]
{{colend}}

== See also ==

 ****** List of C-pop artists

b"{{unreferenced|date=March 2013}}
{{use dmy dates|date=March 2013}}
This is a list of [[C-pop]] artist and groups. C-pop, which encompasses mainly [[Mandopop]] and [[Cantopop]] (and to some extent [[Taiwanese pop|Hokkien pop]] and pop music of other [[Varieties of Chinese|Chinese dialects]]), represents the main [[pop music]] in the [[People's Republic of China]], [[Taiwan]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Macau]] and [[Singapore]], as well as [[Overseas Chinese|Chinese-speaking communities in the rest of the world]].

Almost all popular actors and actresses in Chinese entertainment have released songs to boost their popularity, and thus technically are considered C-pop artists. The list below only includes those whose musical careers are significant, although that is hard to define objectively.

Popular [[Chinese rock|Chinese-rock]] and [[Chinese hip hop|Chinese-hip-hop]] artists are also included.
{{Dynamic list|date=March 2013}}

 ****** List of Carnatic instrumentalists

b'{{Carnatic}}

This is a list of Carnatic instrumentalists: musicians famous for playing the [[carnatic music]] of [[South India]]. Musicians are listed by the instrument they have played.

==Bowed strings==

===[[Violin]]===
[[File:DWARAM.JPG|thumb|Dwaram Venkataswamy Naidu playing a violin]]

* [[Mysore brothers]]

* [[A. Kanyakumari]]
* [[Ganesh and Kumaresh]]
* [[M. Narmadha]]
* [[Vittal Ramamurthy]]
* [[V. V. Ravi]]
* [[Nedumangad Sivanandan]]

 ****** List of Christian dance, electronic, and techno artists

b'{{Unreferenced|date=September 2009}}
List of notable  notable [[electronic music|electronic]], [[techno]], [[dance music|dance]] and [[CEDM]] [[Contemporary Christian music]] artists that play Christian electronic music.

Note: Because classifying music by [[music genre|subgenre]] can be arbitrary, many artists appear on multiple lists of music genres. Furthermore, artists listed have had reputable album releases and are widely accepted by DJs & fans of Christian EDM worldwide as electronic artists.

== Artists ==
{{div col||20em}}
* [[And Then There Were None (band)|And Then There Were None]]
* [[Bash-n-the-Code]] (aka Bash, originally Found Free)
* [[Scott Blackwell]]
* [[The Brothers Martin]]
* [[Capital Kings]]
* [[Cloud2Ground]]
* [[Code of Ethics (band)|Code of Ethics]]
* [[Crumb\xc3\xa4cher]]
* [[The Echoing Green (band)|The Echoing Green]]
* [[Todd Edwards]]
* [[G-Powered]]
* [[Hillsong Music Australia|Hillsong Young & Free]]
* [[Andy Hunter (DJ)|Andy Hunter]]
* [[Joy Electric]]
* [[Leiahdorus]]
* [[LZ7]]
* [[Mad at the World]]
* [[Matthew Parker]]
* [[Mortal (band)|Mortal]]
* [[Owl City]]
* [[Purified (rapper)|Purified]]
* [[Press Play (band)|Press Play]]
* [[Quickflight]]
* [[Raze (Christian pop group)|Raze]]
* [[Salt of the Sound]]
* [[Ultrabeat (Swedish band)|Ultrabeat]]
* [[V*Enna]]
* [[The Tribe (dance band)|World Wide Message Tribe]] also known as "The Tribe"
{{div col end}}

=== Disc jockeys ===
The following disc jockeys from around the world that have made a significant contribution to the Christian electronic scene (not necessarily \'\'Christian\'\' DJs) through mixsets, mixtapes, remixes, podcasts and the like:
* [[Scott Blackwell]]
* [[Andy Hunter (DJ)|Andy Hunter]]

=== Crossover artists ===
The following artists are considered more to be [[contemporary Christian music]], [[Christian rock]] or [[Christian hip hop]] but have released a few songs, an album, EP or [[remix album]] in the [[electronic music]] genre:

{{div col||30em}}
* [[The Afters]] ("Every Good Thing")
* [[Audio Adrenaline]] (\'\'Don\'t Censor Me EP Remixes\'\')
* [[Avalon (band)|Avalon]] (\'\'[[O2: Avalon Remixed]]\'\')
* [[BarlowGirl]] (\'\'Never Alone remixed\'\')
* [[Carman (singer)|Carman]] (various songs)
* [[Casting Crowns]] (various songs)
* [[David Crowder Band]] (\'\'[[Sunsets & Sushi]]\'\')
* [[Delirious?]]  (various songs)
* [[Family Force 5]] (\'\'[[Dance or Die (Family Force 5 album)|Dance or Die]]\'\', \'\'[[Dance or Die with a Vengeance]]\'\') <small>Solomon Olds (Soul Glow Activatur) has done electronic music remixes for other artists as well.</small>
* [[Amy Grant]] (\'\'Amy Grant Remixes Collection\'\', \'\'Remix Collection\'\')
* [[Group 1 Crew]] (\'\'[[Outta Space Love]]\'\', some tracks on \'\'[[Fearless (Group 1 Crew album)|Fearless]]\'\')
* [[Rachael Lampa]] (\'\'[[Blur (Rachael Lampa album)|Blur]]\'\', \'\'[[All We Need]]\'\')
* [[The Letter Black]] (\'\'Hanging On By a Remix\'\')
* [[Manic Drive]] (various songs)
* [[Mary Mary]] (various remixes on singles)
* [[Krystal Meyers]] (\'\'[[Make Some Noise (Krystal Meyers album)|Make Some Noise]]\'\')
* [[MercyMe]]  ("I Can Only Imagine: Digital Aura Mix")
* [[Mutemath]] ("Typical Josh Harris Remix")
* [[Leigh Nash]] (\'\'My Idea of Heaven EP\'\', featured on [[Delerium]]\'s "Innocente")
* [[Newsboys]] (\'\'[[Newsboys Remixed]]\'\', \'\'[[GO Remixed]]\'\', four tracks on \'\'[[Born Again (Newsboys album)|Born Again: Miracles Edition]]\'\' and other tracks)
* [[Britt Nicole]] (\'\'[[Gold (Britt Nicole album)|Gold]]\'\')
* [[Stacie Orrico]] (various remixes on singles)
* [[Plumb (singer)|Plumb]] (\'\'In My Arms Remixes\'\' and \'\'Beautiful History: Bonus Remixes\'\')
* [[Press Play (band)|Press Play]] (\'\'Ny2La\'\', and \'\'World Anthem\'\')
* [[Rebecca St. James]] (\'\'[[Rebecca St. James: Extended Play Remixes]]\'\', \'\'[[Transform (Rebecca St. James album)|Transform]]\'\')
* [[Royal Tailor]] (Several tracks including collaborations with [[Capital Kings]])
* [[Beckah Shae]] (\'\'Destiny\'\')
* [[Shonlock]] (tracks on \'\'Neveroddoreven\'\' and \'\'A Night to Remember\'\')
* [[Michael W. Smith]] (\'\'Tresice Remixes\'\')
* [[Superchick]] ([[Regeneration (Superchick album)|Regeneration]], [[Reinvention (Superchick album)|Reinvention]])
* [[Steve Taylor]] ([[Meltdown (Steve Taylor album)|Meltdown]] remixes, and \'\'Transatlantic Remixes\'\'))
* [[Thousand Foot Krutch]] (\'\'[[Metamorphosiz: The End Remixes Vol. 1]]\'\', \'\'[[Metamorphosiz: The End Remixes Vol. 2]]\'\')

 ****** List of 1970s Christian pop artists

b'List of notable Contemporary Christian Music artists from the 1970s.

The \'\'Encyclopedia of Contemporary Christian Music\'\' (2002) defines CCM as "music that appeals to self-identified fans of [[Contemporary Christian Music|contemporary Christian music]] on account of a perceived connection to what they regard as [[Christianity]]".<ref name="Powell_Fe">{{cite book |last=Powell |first=Mark Allan |title=Encyclopedia of Contemporary Christian Music |year=2002 |publisher=Hendrickson Publishers |location=[[Peabody, Massachusetts|Peabody]], [[Massachusetts]] |isbn=1-56563-679-1 |edition=First printing |page=13}}</ref> Based on this definition, this list includes artists that work in the [[Christian music industry]] as well as artists in the [[music industry|general market]].

 ****** List of Christian vocal artists

b'List of notable [[Vocal music|vocal]] Christian artists.

The \'\'Encyclopedia of Contemporary Christian Music\'\' (2002) defines CCM as "music that appeals to self-identified fans of [[Contemporary Christian Music|contemporary Christian music]] on account of a perceived connection to what they regard as [[Christianity]]".<ref name="Powell_Fe">{{cite book |last=Powell |first=Mark Allan |title=Encyclopedia of Contemporary Christian Music |year=2002 |publisher=Hendrickson Publishers |location=[[Peabody, Massachusetts|Peabody]], [[Massachusetts]] |isbn=1-56563-679-1 |edition=First printing |page=13}}</ref> Based on this definition, this list includes artists that work in the [[Christian music industry]] as well as artists in the [[music industry|general market]].

Note: Because classifying music by [[music genre|genre]] can be arbitrary, these groupings are generalized and many artists appear on multiple lists.
* [[Acappella (group)|Acappella]]
* [[Acapella Vocal Band|AVB (a.k.a. Acappella Vocal Band)]]
* [[David M. Bailey]]
* [[First Call]]
* [[Holly Starr]]
* [[4Him]]
* [[The Imperials]]
* [[Ladysmith Black Mambazo]]
* [[Michael W. Smith]]
* [[NewSong]]
* [[Sandi Patty]]
* [[Take 6]]

[[Category:Country musicians| ]]
[[Category:Country singers| ]]
[[Category:Country music groups| ]]
[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Country]]'

 ****** List of country performers by era

b'{{unreferenced|date=March 2009}}
Below is a list of notable country performers alphabetically by period, with each listing followed by a description of the artists\' work.
{{dynamic list|date=April 2013}}

==Early innovators==
{{div col|colwidth=30em}}
*[[Vernon Dalhart]] recorded hundreds of songs until 1931.
*[[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]], first country superstar, the undisputed "Father of Country Music".
*[[The Carter Family]], rural country-folk, known for hits like "Wildwood Flower".
*[[Uncle Dave Macon]], banjo player, singer, and songwriter who became the first star of the Grand Ole Opry in the late 1920s
*[[Roy Acuff]] Grand Ole Opry star for 50 years, "King of Country Music".
*[[Jenny Lou Carson]], the first female to write a No.&nbsp;1 Country Hit (1945) "[[You Two-Timed Me One Time Too Often]]".
*[[Patsy Montana]], the first female Country singer to sell 1 million records.
*[[Girls of the Golden West]], one of the first Country music duo groups.
*[[Ernest Tubb]] Beloved Texas troubadour who helped scores become stars.
*[[Al Dexter]], a country musician and songwriter, best known for "Pistol Packin\' Mama," a 1944 hit that was one of the most popular recordings of the World War II years.
*[[Red Foley]], the first major country star after World War II, host of \'\'[[Ozark Jubilee]]\'\'
*[[Hank Snow]] Canadian-born Grand Ole Opry star famous for his traveling songs.
*[[Hank Williams]] pioneer, singer, and songwriter, known for hits including "I\'m So Lonesome I Could Cry", "Your Cheatin\'   Heart" and "[[Jambalaya (On the Bayou)]]".
*[[Bill Monroe]], father of [[bluegrass music]].
*[[The Davis Sisters (country)|The Davis Sisters]], best known for the hit "[[I Forgot More Than You\'ll Ever Know]]"
*[[Louvin Brothers]], inspired the [[Everly Brothers]].
*[[Little Jimmy Dickens]] 4-foot 11&nbsp;inch star of the Grand Ole Opry.
*[[Goldie Hill]], the "golden hillbilly", best known for the hit song "I Let the Stars Get in My Eyes".
*[[Wilf Carter (musician)|Wilf Carter]], the "yodeling" cowboy, aka [[Montana Slim]].
*[[Jean Shepard]], one of Country\'s leading female vocalists in the 1950s.
*[[Webb Pierce]], classic honky-tonker who dominated \'50s country music.
*[[Kitty Wells]], country\'s first female superstar, called the "[[Queen of Country Music]]".
*[[Johnny Cash]] created the boom-chicka-boom sound and recorded music from 1954 to 2003.
*[[Ray Price (musician)|Ray Price]], created the 4/4 shuffle which transformed traditional country music.
*[[Glen Campbell]], "The Rhinestone Cowboy," legendary session guitarist who launched out as a solo act and broke Country Music\'s 3-chord barrier and popularized "The Nashville sound" known for lush string and orchestral arrangements.
*[[Woody Guthrie]], wrote and sang the song "This Land Land is Your Land" and is cited by musicians from many genres as an inspiration.
*[[Bob Wills]], considered by many artist to be the real king of country music
{{div col end}}

==Performers of The Golden Age and [[country pop]] in the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s==
{{div col|colwidth=30em}}
*[[Bill Anderson (country music)|Bill Anderson]], singer who is still a major songwriter of new hits
*[[Liz Anderson]], as famous for her songwriting as her singing; mother of Lynn Anderson
*[[Lynn Anderson]], a California blonde who became a major country star in the 70s; helped by regular exposure on national television, was one of the first female artists to achieve major crossover success. Has won CMA, ACM, AMA, & Grammy Awards.  Named Billboard\'s "Artist of the Decade" (70-80).
*[[Deborah Allen]], a popular 80s Country/Pop vocalist
*[[Eddy Arnold]], the all-time hit leader by [[Joel Whitburn]]\'s point system
*[[Moe Bandy]], singer of the 70s/80s; paired with Joe Stampley on a series of recordings
*[[The Browns]], brother-sister trio
*[[Glen Campbell]], brought a whole new audience to Country Music with his TV show, co-starred with John Wayne in movie "True Grit," won many awards, top Country Music hitmaker and pop crossover icon.  He popularized "The Nashville Sound."
*[[Johnny Cash]], one of the single most Influential and popular country singers of all time. Best known for hits like "[[Ring of Fire (song)|Ring of Fire]]", "[[Folsom Prison Blues]]" and "[[Cocaine Blues]]".  He died in 2003
*[[Patsy Cline]], immensely popular balladeer who died in 1963
*[[David Allan Coe]], Outlaw Country star of the 70s
*[[Jessi Colter]], Outlaw country singer and wife of [[Waylon Jennings]], best known for "[[I\'m Not Lisa]]"
*[[John Conlee]], had a string of hits from the late 70s to mid 80s, including his signature "Rose Colored Glasses
*[[Skeeter Davis]], major female vocalist for decades
*[[Mac Davis]], [[Country Pop]] hitmaker in the 70s and 80s
*[[Jimmy Dean]], singer and TV personality, former owner of Jimmy Dean Sausage Company
*[[John Denver]],singer/songwriter of numerous hit songs throughout the 1970s including \'\'Annies song\'\',\'\'Back Home Again\'\',and \'\'Take Me Home,Country Roads\'\'. John Denver died in 1997.
*[[Roy Drusky]], smooth-singing Opry star for 40 years
*[[Jimmy Martin]], The King of bluegrass
*[[Janie Fricke]], known for her series of smooth [[Countrypolitan]] hits in the early 80s
*[[Lefty Frizzell]], perhaps the greatest of the honky-tonkers
*[[Crystal Gayle]], sister of [[Loretta Lynn]] who became a [[Countrypolitan]] sensation in the 70s and 80s and had 18 No.&nbsp;1\'s during this stretch.
*[[Bobbie Gentry]], one of the first female artists to write and produce her own material.
*[[Don Gibson]], wrote and recorded many standards
*[[Merle Haggard]], popularized the [[Bakersfield sound]]
*[[Tom T. Hall]], "The Storyteller", wrote most of his many hits
*[[Emmylou Harris]] has maintained one of the most artistically rewarding careers in country music
*[[Johnny Horton]] a fantastic singer who met an untimely death that ended a wonderful career.
*[[Jan Howard]], pop-flavored female vocalist who sang pure country
*[[Stonewall Jackson (musician)|Stonewall Jackson]], honky-tonk icon
*[[Sonny James]], had a record 16 consecutive No. 1 hits
*[[Wanda Jackson]], honky-tonk female vocalist equally at home in [[rock and roll]]
*[[Waylon Jennings]], one of the leaders of the "outlaw"  country sound
*[[George Jones]],once widely considered "the greatest living country singer", No.&nbsp;1 in charted hits
#[[Dick Curless]], [[Singer/songwriter]] known mostly for his trucking songs.
*[[Kris Kristofferson]], [[songwriter]] and one of the leaders of the "outlaw" country sound
*[[k.d. lang]], Canadian country-pop singer-songwriter, known for her campy performances, androgynous look, and mezzo-soprano range, winning CCMA\'s Entertainer of the Year Award in 1987, 1988, 1989, and 1990, Best Album 1988 for Shadowland, and the American Grammy Awards for Best Country Vocal Collaboration 1989 for "Crying" (shared with Roy Orbison), and Best Female Country Music Performance 1990, for Absolute Torch and Twang.
*[[Myrna Lorrie]], the first Lady of Canadian Country Music.
*[[Loretta Lynn]], arguably country music\'s biggest star in the 1960s and early 1970s.
*[[Barbara Mandrell]], first artist to win Country Music Entertainer of the Year back to back. 1980 and 1981 from both the ACM & CMA. Known for having songs crossover to the pop charts. Had the last successful country music variety show on NBC 1980-1982. Had multiple hits in the late 70\'s thru the late 80\'s. Could sing, dance and play over 10+ instruments.
*[[Roger Miller]], songwriter and Grammy record-breaker
*[[Ronnie Milsap]], country\'s first blind superstar and arguably the most popular country star of the late 1970s and early 1980s; scored 40 No.&nbsp;1 hits (35 of which reached the top spot on Billboard)
*[[Melba Montgomery]], duet vocalist in the 60s, who launched a solo career in the 70s
*[[Anne Murray]], Prominent Canadian country-pop vocalist best known for the songs Snowbird, Could I Have This Dance, You Needed Me and other hits in the 1970s-1980s.
*[[Willie Nelson]], [[songwriter]] and one of the leaders of the [[outlaw country]] sound
*[[Mickey Newbury]], singer/songwriter started the lyric revolution in Nashville with his 1969 album [[Looks Like Rain]]. He wrote over 500 songs and has over 1000 covers to date. He was a songwriter\'s songwriter.
*[[Marie Osmond]], Youngest female to date to have a No.&nbsp;1 country hit, with "[[Paper Roses]]" in 1973, and also had a string of country hits in the mid-1980s such as;"[[Meet Me in Montana]]" (with [[Dan Seals]]), "There\'s No Stopping Your Heart", "Read My Lips", "You\'re Still New To Me" (with [[Paul Davis (singer)|Paul Davis]]), and "I Only Wanted You".
*[[Norma Jean (singer)|Norma Jean]], gifted "hard country" vocalist, known also as [[Pretty Miss Norma Jean]]
*[[Buck Owens]], Hottest artist of the \'60s, pioneer innovator of the [[Bakersfield sound]]
*[[Dolly Parton]], one of the most successful female country artist in history
*[[Ray Price (musician)|Ray Price]], traditional country star of the \'50s and \'60s, who experienced pop success in the \'70s and \'80s
*[[Charley Pride]], the first black country music star
*[[Jeanne Pruett]], female vocalist of the 70s, best known for the song "[[Satin Sheets]]"
*[[Bonnie Raitt]], an American blues singer-songwriter and a renowned slide guitar player
*[[Susan Raye]], Buck Owens\' prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9e who became a solo star with moderate success
*[[Jim Reeves]], crossover artist, invented [[Nashville Sound]] with [[Chet Atkins]]
*[[Charlie Rich]], \'50s rock star who enjoyed greatest success in \'70s country
*[[Marty Robbins]], one of the most popular artists in country music history.  Named artist of the decade (1960\xe2\x80\x931969) by the [[Academy of Country Music]]
*[[Jeannie C. Riley]], sexy girl in a miniskirt who socked it to the pop charts with "[[Harper Valley PTA]]."
*[[Kenny Rogers]], unique-voiced storyteller who also recorded love ballads and more rock material. He defined what was known as [[country crossover]] and became one of the biggest artists in country and any music genre.
*[[Jeannie Seely]], known as "Miss Country Soul"
*[[Billy Joe Shaver]], songwriter, wrote all but one song on Waylon Jennings\' groundbreaking Honky Tonk Heroes album
*[[Connie Smith]], recorded "[[Once a Day]], the longest stay at No.&nbsp;1 for any female country artist
*[[Margo Smith]], known for her sexy come-on songs
*[[Sammi Smith]], best known for her "husky" voice and 1971 hit song "[[Help Me Make It Through the Night]]"
*[[Sylvia (singer)|Sylvia]], Countrypolitan sensation the early to mid-80s
*[[Billie Jo Spears]], a hard-country vocalist with primarily international popularity
*[[Ray Stevens]], comedy crossover artist, Branson businessman
*[[Mel Tillis]], country music legend and father of country singer Pam Tillis.
*[[Tanya Tucker]], teen Country star whose career later spanned well beyond her teen years
*[[Conway Twitty]], scored 55 No.&nbsp;1 hits(The most all time)
*[[Townes Van Zandt]], songwriter, troubador
*[[Porter Wagoner]], pioneer on country television
*[[Gene Watson]], [[Texas]] country music cult legend, who gained national success after [[Love in the Hot Afternoon]]
*[[Dottie West]], one of Country music\'s most influential and groundbreaking female artists
*[[The Wilburn Brothers]], popular male duet for decades
*[[Don Williams]], aka "The Gentle Giant" with many popular hits
*[[Hank Williams, Jr.]], Leader in the Outlaw country movement. Multi-instrumental talent, and song writing star. Won several awards. Son of Hank Williams Sr.
*[[Tammy Wynette]], three-time CMA top female vocalist
*[[Faron Young]], a country chart topper for three decades
*[[Ferlin Husky]], country music singer who was equally adept at the genres of traditional honky honk, ballads, spoken recitations, and rockabilly pop tunes
*[[Hank Locklin]], early honky-tonk singer-songwriter who had hits that charted from 1949\xe2\x80\x931971
{{div col end}}

==[[Country rock|Country-rock]] performers==
{{main|List of country rock musicians}}
{{div col|colwidth=30em}}<!--Please keep in alpha order-->
*[[38 Special (band)|.38 Special]]
*[[The Allman Brothers Band]], the most successful southern rock band in history
*[[The Band]], started out backing up [[Bob Dylan]] and their [[Music from Big Pink]] is a classic record
*[[Black Oak Arkansas]]
*[[Blackberry Smoke]]
*[[Blackfoot (band)|Blackfoot]]
*[[The Byrds]]
*[[Charlie Daniels Band]]
*[[Gene Clark]]
*[[Commander Cody and His Lost Planet Airmen]]
*[[Creedence Clearwater Revival]], songs like [[Born on the Bayou]] helped to create the country rock genre
*[[Desert Rose Band]]
*[[The Eagles]], a very popular country rock band
*[[The Everly Brothers]], predated others in this category but important figures in the transition from [[rockabilly]] to [[country rock]]
*[[The First Edition (band)|The First Edition]]
*[[Flying Burrito Brothers]]
*[[Kinky Friedman]]
*[[Grateful Dead]], extremely long-lived bluegrass and [[psychedelic rock|psychedelic]] band
*[[Emmylou Harris]]
*[[Heartsfield]]
*[[Kane (US band)|KANE]]
*[[The Kentucky Headhunters]]
*[[Chris LeDoux]]
*[[Lynyrd Skynyrd]], a very popular southern rock band
*[[Marshall Tucker Band]]
*[[Ricky Nelson]], in the latter stage of his career, particularly on songs such as "Garden Party"
*[[Michael Nesmith]]
*[[New Riders of the Purple Sage]]
*[[Juice Newton]], the top-selling female country rocker of the 1980s
*[[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]]
*[[Ozark Mountain Daredevils]]
*[[Gram Parsons]], a pioneer of the country-rock and alt-country sound. A member of the International Submarine Band, The Byrds, and The Flying Burrito Brothers. 
*[[Poco]]
*[[Pure Prairie League]] ([[Vince Gill]] was the lead singer of this group on their biggest pop hit, 1980s "Let Me Love You Tonight.")
*[[John Rich (musician)|John Rich]]
*[[Linda Ronstadt]], in 1978 Country Music Magazine put her on the cover with the title "Queen Of Country Rock".
*[[Southern Pacific (band)]]
*[[Gary Stewart (singer)|Gary Stewart]] honky tonker and southern rocker, legendary throughout the \'70s and early \'80s.
*[[Steve Young (musician)|Steve Young]]
*[[Sasha Pieterse]]
{{div col end}}

==Late-1990s country-music performers==
{{div col|colwidth=30em}}<!--Please keep in alpha order-->

[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Country rock]]
[[Category:Country rock musicians| ]]'

 ****** List of crooners

b'{{multiple issues|
{{more footnotes|date=January 2013}}
{{original research|date=January 2013}}
{{refimprove|date=January 2013}}
}}
This is a list of [[crooner]]s\xe2\x80\x94singers in a soft, intimate style made possible by the introduction of [[microphone]]s and [[amplifier|amplification]].<ref name=Cam>{{citation|url=http://books.google.com/?id=3xN925VIrsgC&pg=PA347|page=347|title=The Cambridge companion to modern American culture|author=C. W. E. Bigsby|isbn=978-0-521-84132-0|year=2006}}</ref> "Crooner" is an American [[epithet]] given to male singers of [[pop standards]], mostly from the [[Great American Songbook]], either backed by a full [[orchestra]], a [[big band]] or by a piano. Originally it was an [[ironic]] term denoting an emphatically sentimental, often emotional singing style made possible by the use of microphones.

 ****** List of dance-rock artists

b'{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}}
The following list includes notable [[dance-rock]] artists.

==Artists==
{{div col|3}}
* [[!!!]]<ref>{{cite news|first= Andy |last= Beta |title= !!! * [[Scissor Sisters]]<ref name="Dance-rock"/><ref>{{cite journal|first= Michael |last= Paoletta |title= Inside Track |date= 17 June 2006 |magazine= Billboard |publisher= Nielsen Business Media |url= http://books.google.com?id=ShYEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA90&dq=%22dance+rock%22 |volume= 118 |issue= 24 |page= 90 |issn= 0006-2510}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first= Dan |last= Weiss |title= The Scissor Sisters make scandalous disco-rock |newspaper= [[SF Weekly]] |url= http://www.sfweekly.com/2010-09-08/music/the-scissor-sisters-make-scandalous-disco-rock/full/ |date= 8 September 2010 |accessdate= 1 March 2014}}</ref>
* [[The Shamen]]<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.trouserpress.com/entry.php?a=shamen |first= Ira |last= Robbins |title= Shamen |work= Trouser Press |quote= the Shamen reoriented themselves to play simplified dance rock on the pointedly political but boringly de-Shamenized In Gorbachev We Trust. |accessdate= 1 March 2014}}</ref>
* [[Simple Minds]]<ref>{{cite news|first= Jane |last= Stevenson |title= Simple Minds make triumphant return to Toronto |newspaper= [[Toronto Sun]] |date= 23 October 2013 |url= http://www.torontosun.com/2013/10/23/simple-minds-make-triumphant-return-to-toronto |accessdate= 28 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Simple Minds |url= http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/Whats-on-leisure/Reviews/Simple-Minds-22062013.htm |newspaper= [[Cambridge News]] |quote= Simple Minds, lest we forget, were doing Teutonic dance-rock a good decade before U2 decamped to Berlin with Brian Eno |date= 22 June 2013 |accessdate= 28 February 2014}}</ref>
* [[The Stone Roses]]<ref name="Whitelaw"/><ref>{{cite news|first= Gil |last= Kaufman |title= Ex-Stone Roses Singer Not Just Monkeying Around On New LP |publisher= [[MTV]]. [[Viacom International]]. |url= http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/2883/ex-stone-roses-singer-not-just-monkeying-around-on-new-lp.jhtml |quote= The Stone Roses were among the leaders of the druggy, dance-rock Manchester scene of the mid- to late \'80s |date= 31 January 1998 |accessdate= 1 March 2014}}</ref>
* [[Talking Heads]]<ref>{{cite journal|url= http://books.google.com/?id=KiQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA20&dq=%22dance+rock%22 |first= Brian |last= Chin |title= Dance Tracks |magazine= Billboard |volume= 97 |issue= 25 |date= 22 June 1985 |publisher= Nielsen Business Media |quote= It\'s a throwback to the Heads\' pre-funk dance-rock sound |page= 61 |issn= 0006-2510}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Head Games: \'Talking Heads: Chronology\' |format= PDF |url= http://kayosproductions.com/files/583_Talking%20Heads%20-%20PopMatters.pdf |publisher= PopMatters |quote= |date= 22 February 2012 |accessdate= 28 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first= Don |last= Shewey |title= David Byrne keeps on making sense |url= http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1959&dat=19860923&id=jp8oAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xIcFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4578,5738550 |quote= It\'s a far cry not just from Talking Heads\' nervous dance rock but also from the experiments with "found" sound on \'\'My Life in the Bush of Ghosts\'\' |newspaper= [[The Phoenix (newspaper)|The Boston Phoenix]] |date= 23 September 1986 |page= 4}}</ref>
* [[Tom Tom Club]]<ref>{{cite news|first= Mike |last= Boehm |title= 3 Talking Heads Plus 5 Equals Concert |url= http://articles.latimes.com/1990-08-02/entertainment/ca-1620_1_something-talking-heads |newspaper= Los Angeles Times |quote= Frantz and Weymouth\'s dance-rock band, the Tom Tom Club |date= 2 August 1990 |accessdate= 28 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title= Encyclopedia of Punk Music and Culture |first= Brian |last= Cogan |publisher= [[Greenwood Publishing Group]] |quote= Bassist Tina Weymouth and drummer Chris Frantz also play in the dance rock band Tom Tom Club. |year= 2006 |isbn= 978-0-3133-3340-8 |page= 225}}</ref>
* [[U2]]<ref name="Dance-rock"/><ref>{{cite web|first= Evan |last= Sawdey |title= U2: No Line on the Horizon |publisher= PopMatters |url= http://www.popmatters.com/review/71028-u2-no-line-on-the-horizon/ |quote= After the breakthrough 1991 album \'\'Achtung Baby\'\', this group of working-class Irish lads slowly began losing themselves in the pre-millennial dance-rock craze |date= 1 March 2009 |accessdate= 1 March 2014}}</ref>
* [[Was (Not Was)]]<ref>{{cite journal|url= http://www.americansongwriter.com/2011/10/the-2011-americana-music-awards-that-old-time-rock-and-roll/ |title= The 2011 Americana Music Awards: That Old Time Rock and Roll |first= Jewly |last= Hight |quote= Don Was, member of \'80s dance-rock outfit Was (Not Was) and producer of the Rolling Stones |magazine= [[American Songwriter]] |date= 14 October 2011 |accessdate= 27 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first= Sarah |last= Rodman |title= Was (Not Was) is again with new CD |publisher= [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|JS Online]] |url= http://www.jsonline.com/entertainment/musicandnightlife/29529134.html |date= 7 May 2008 |accessdate= 27 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://articles.mcall.com/2005-01-06/entertainment/3595364_1_paula-abdul-dreaming-band |first= Len |last= Righi |title= Dance-rock band Was (now Was) ready to walk the dinosaur again |newspaper= [[The Morning Call]] |date= 6 January 2005 |accessdate= 27 February 2014}}</ref>
* [[Robbie Williams]]<ref name="Dance-rock"/>

 ****** List of death metal bands

b"'''Lists of death metal bands''' can be found at:
* [[List of death metal bands, !\xe2\x80\x93K]], for bands beginning with !-9 through K
* [[List of death metal bands, L\xe2\x80\x93Z]], for bands beginning with L through Z

[[Category:Death metal]]
[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Death metal]]"

 ****** List of deathcore artists

b'The following is a list of deathcore artists. [[Deathcore]] is an [[extreme metal]] fusion genre that combines the characteristics of [[death metal]] and [[metalcore]].<ref name=whatis>[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r704417|pure_url=yes}} allmusic.com] Alex Henderson: "What is deathcore? ...it\'s essentially metalcore... Drawing on both death metal and hardcore..."</ref><ref name="allmusic heaven">{{cite web|last=Rivadavia|first=Eduardo|title=Heaven Shall Burn|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/p519192|work=[[AllMusic]]|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=25 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Henderson|first=Alex|title=Burning Skies|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/burning-skies-p671407/biography|work=[[AllMusic]]|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=25 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Gorania|first=Jay H.|title=Despised Icon - \'Day Of Mourning\'|url=http://heavymetal.about.com/od/d/gr/despisedicon-dayofmourning.htm|publisher=[[About.com]]|accessdate=25 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Henderson|first=Alex|title=Desolation of Eden|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/r1714463|work=[[AllMusic]]|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=25 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="breakdown">[http://www.lambgoat.com/albums/view.aspx?id=2517 lambgoat.com] "This is deathcore. This is what happens when death metal and hardcore, along with healthy doses of other heavy music styles, are so smoothly blended..."</ref> It is defined by death metal [[Ostinato#Riff|riffs]], [[blast beat]]s and use of metalcore [[Break (music)#Metal and punk|breakdowns]].<ref name="Cosmo Lee">{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Cosmo|title=Doom|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/r854978|work=[[AllMusic]]|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=25 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Marsicano|first=Dan|title=Rose Funeral - \'The Resting Sonata\'|url=http://heavymetal.about.com/od/cdreviews/gr/rosefuneralrest.htm|publisher=[[About.com]]|accessdate=25 March 2011}}</ref> Deathcore gained most prominence within the [[southwestern United States]], especially [[Arizona]] and inland [[southern California]] (mostly the [[Coachella Valley]]), which are home to many notable bands and various festivals.<ref>[http://userserve-ak.last.fm/serve/_/2929615.jpg Official SoCal DeathFest banner - held in Santa Ana, California]</ref><ref>[http://img20.imageshack.us/img20/914/flyeranimositymtyfinalcei2.gif Official Deathcore Fest banner - held in San Francisco, California]</ref><ref>[http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=77493 roadrunnerrecords.com] "Ferret Music has announced the signing of ELYSIA. The California-based deathcore outfit is composed of Zak Vargas (vocals), Mark Underwood (guitar), Steven Sessler (drums), Danny Lemonsqueeze (guitar) and Jeremy Chavez (bass, backing vocals) and formed four years ago"</ref><ref>[http://www.pyromusic.net/index.php?p=reviews_review&review=Suicide_Silence-The_Cleansing&id=1178 pyromusic.net] Spiritech: "..., meet Californian quintet Suicide Silence, who have just released their debut album, \'The Cleansing\'."</ref>

{{Compact ToC|num=yes|side=yes|center=yes|h=H|l=L|p=P|q=Q|w=W|x=X|y=Y|z=Z|seealso=yes|nobreak=yes}}
{{Dynamic list}}

==Artists==

===A===

* [[The Agonist]]<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p893871|pure_url=yes}}|title=Agonist > Biography|last=Rivadavia|first=Eduardo|work=Allmusic|publisher=Macrovision|accessdate=3 July 2009}}</ref>
* [[The Agony Scene]]<ref>{{cite web |author=Rivadavia, Eduardo |title=The Agony Scene |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p560649|pure_url=yes}} |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=2009-11-27}}</ref>
* [[All Shall Perish]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://heavymetal.about.com/od/cdreviews/fr/allshallawaken.htm|title=All Shall Perish - Awaken the Dreamers Review|last=Bowar|first=Chad|work=About.com|publisher=The New York Times Company|accessdate=3 July 2009}}</ref>
* [[Animosity (band)|Animosity]]<ref name="Dawn of the Deathcore" />
* [[Arsonists Get All the Girls]]<ref name=arsonists>{{cite web |author=Sharpe-Young, Garry |title=Arsonists Get All The Girls |url=http://www.musicmight.com/artist/united+states/california/santa+cruz/arsonists+get+all+the+girls1 |publisher=[[MusicMight]] |accessdate=2009-07-10}}</ref>
* [[Asesino]]<ref>{{cite web |author=Born, R and Sharpe-Young, Garry |title=Asesino |url=http://www.musicmight.com/artist/united+states/california/los+angeles/asesino |publisher=[[MusicMight]] |accessdate=2009-07-14}}</ref>
* [[As Blood Runs Black]]<ref>{{cite web |author=Rosenberg, Axl |title=\'\'Instinct\'\': As Blood Runs Blah |date=22 February 2011 |url=http://www.metalsucks.net/2011/02/22/instinct-as-blood-runs-blah/ |publisher=[[MetalSucks]] |accessdate=21 January 2015 |quote=The band seems to play two styles of music ... : modern death metal ... and standard deathcore.}}</ref>
* [[Attila (metalcore band)|Attila]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://loudwire.com/attila-announce-new-album-about-that-life-release-song-middle-fingers-up/|title=Attila Announce New Album \xe2\x80\x98About That Life\xe2\x80\x99 + Release Song \xe2\x80\x98Middle Fingers Up\xe2\x80\x99|work=[[Loudwire]]|publisher=[[Townsquare Media]]|accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref>

===B===

 ****** List of doom metal bands

b'This is an alphabetical list of [[doom metal]] bands including [[doom metal#Stoner doom|stoner metal]], [[sludge metal]], [[drone metal]] and [[Doom metal#Funeral doom|funeral doom]], artists that play within a genre that fuses doom metal with another, such as [[death/doom]] and black/doom, and artists that have played doom metal at some point in their career.

{{Compact ToC|q=Q|x=X|num=yes|center=yes|seealso=yes|nobreak=yes|refs=yes}}
{{col-begin}}
{{col-3}}

[[Category:Lists of heavy metal bands|Doom]]
[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Doom metal]]'

 ****** List of dream pop artists

b'This is a list of [[dream pop]] artists. This includes artists who have either been very important to the genre or have had a considerable amount of exposure (such as in the case of one that has been on a major label, but not limited to such). This list does not include little-known local bands. Bands are listed by the first letter in their name (not including the words "a", "an", or "the"), and individuals are listed by last name.

{{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}

 ****** List of dub artists

b'{{Unreferenced|date=January 2009}}
[[Dub music]] is a subgenre of [[reggae]] which developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s.

This is a list of notable dub musicians, singers and producers.

[[Category:Reggae musicians|*]]
[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre]]'

 ****** List of dubstep musicians

b'{{pp-semi-blp|small=yes}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}}
This is a list of [[dubstep]] musicians. This includes artists who have either been very important to the genre or have had a considerable amount of exposure (such as in the case of one that has been on a major label, but not limited to such). This list does not include little-known local artists. Artists are listed by the first letter in their name (not including the words "a", "an", or "the").

{{Compact ToC
|side=yes
|nobreak=yes
|top=no
|num=yes
|sym=no
|seealso=no
|refs=no
|extlinks=no
}}

[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre]]"

 ****** List of Eurodance artists

b'{{Refimprove|date=July 2012}}

The following is a list of Eurodance artists. [[Eurodance]], which is also known as Euro house or Euro-NRG, is a genre of [[electronic dance music]] that originated in the late 1980s primarily in Europe. It combines elements from [[House music|house]], [[techno]], [[Hi-NRG]] and especially [[Euro disco]]. Eurodance production has continued to evolve with a more modernized style that incorporates elements from [[Electro (music)|electro]] and techno music.

{|border="0" align="center" class="toccolours"
!{{MediaWiki:Toc}}
|-
|align="center"|[[#Artists|Artists]]: [[#0\xe2\x80\x939|0\xe2\x80\x939]] [[#A|A]] [[#B|B]] [[#C|C]] [[#D|D]] [[#E|E]] [[#F|F]] [[#G|G]] [[#H|H]] [[#I|I]] [[#J|J]] [[#K|K]] [[#L|L]] [[#M|M]] [[#N|N]] [[#O|O]] [[#P|P]] [[#R|R]] [[#S|S]] [[#T|T]] [[#U|U]] [[#V|V]] [[#W|W]] [[#X|X]] [[#Y|Y]] [[#Z|Z]]<br>[[#Successful Eurodance songs|Successful Eurodance songs]]
__NOTOC__
|}

[[Category:Eurodance]]
[[Category:Lists of dance artists|Eurodance]]
[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Eurodance]]'

 ****** List of Europop artists

b'{{Refimprove|date=October 2013}}
[[Europop]] refers to a style of pop music that first developed in today\'s form in Europe, throughout the late 1970s. Europop topped the charts throughout the 1980s and 1990s. Some Europop stars came from France, Germany, Italy, Ireland, Netherlands and the United Kingdom, but most were [[Swedes|Swedish]] in origin. In the 1970s, such groups were primarily popular in continental countries, with the exception of the biggest Europop outfit ever, Swedish 4-piece [[ABBA]], who achieved great success in the UK, where they scored a 19 top 10 singles and 9 chart-topping albums, and in North America and Australia. In the late 1980s and early 1990s, [[Roxette]] and [[Ace of Base]] led Europop in American and British mainstream audiences. In the 1990s, pop groups like the [[Spice Girls]], [[Aqua (band)|Aqua]], [[Backstreet Boys]] and singer [[DJ BoBo]] were strongly influenced by Europop. In the 2000s, one of the most popular representators of Europop music is Swedish pop group [[Alcazar (band)|Alcazar]]. One of the main differences between American and European [[Pop music|pop]] is that Europop is generally more dance and trance oriented. In central Europe, [[Italo disco]] (a.k.a. \xe2\x80\x9980s Eurodisco) and [[Eurodance|Euro house]] (a.k.a. \xe2\x80\x9990s Eurodance) (later) are the predominant attempts by young musicians to have a hit record in and beyond the borders of their own country.

List of Europop artists:

{{div col|colwidth=30em}}
* [[A Touch of Class (band)|A Touch of Class]] (ATC)<ref>{{cite web|title= ATC \xe2\x80\x93 Artist Biography |first= MacKenzie |last= Wilson |url= http://www.allmusic.com/artist/atc-mn0000486422/biography |publisher= [[AllMusic]]. [[All Media Network]] |accessdate= 23 March 2014}}</ref>

 ****** List of experimental musicians

b'{{Globalize|date=December 2010}}
This is a list of notable [[experimental music]]ians, in alphabetical order by surname.{{Vague|date=May 2013}}<!--These are by no means all alpha by surname, but what do you call names like "Bull of Heaven" or "Experimental Audio Research", which of course should be listed by the first, not the last word in the name?-->

== K-P ==

 ****** List of free improvising musicians and groups

b"{{refimprove|date=November 2008}}
<br />
This is a list of musicians and groups who compose and play free music, or [[free improvisation]]. In alphabetical order:

*[[Massacre (experimental band)|Massacre]]
*[[Maybe Monday]]
*[[Mujician]]
*[[Musica Elettronica Viva]]
*[[nmperign]] (a duo consisting of [[Soprano saxophone|soprano saxophonist]] [[Bhob Rainey]] and trumpeter [[Greg Kelley]])
{{col-2}}
*[[poire z]] \xe2\x80\x93 electronics
*[[Red Square (band)|Red Square]]
*[[San Agustin (Trio)|San Agustin]]
*[[Shaking Ray Levis]]
*[[Skeleton Crew (band)|Skeleton Crew]]
*[[Spontaneous Music Ensemble]]
*[[Supersilent]]
*[[Triangulation]] \xe2\x80\x93 Irish-Swiss-French improv group with [[Christy Doran]], [[John Wolf Brennan]], [[Patrice H\xc3\xa9ral]] and [[Bruno Amstad]]
*[[Un Drame Musical Instantan\xc3\xa9]] and precursor [[Birg\xc3\xa9 Gorg\xc3\xa9 Shiroc]]
*[[Vitamin S]] \xe2\x80\x93 A free improvisation collective

*[[Zoviet France]]

==References==
{{reflist}}

{{Musical improvisation}}

[[Category:Free improvisation| ]]
[[Category:Free improvising musicians| ]]
[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Free improvisation]]"

 ****** List of funk musicians

b'{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}}
This is a list of [[funk]] music artists. This includes artists who <u>have either been very important to the genre</u> or have had a <u>considerable amount of exposure</u> (such as in the case of one that has been on a major label, but not limited to such). Bands are listed by the first letter in their name (not including the words "a", "an", or "the"), and individuals are listed by last name.

{{compact ToC|center=yes|num=yes|nobreak=yes}}

|valign="top" width=33%|

 ****** List of glam punk artists

b'A list of musical acts who belong to the [[glam punk]] subgenre of [[glam rock]] and [[protopunk]] music.

==Glitter punk roots: 1968\xe2\x80\x931979==
{{div col||20em}}
* {{flagicon|USA}} [[Alice Cooper]]
* {{flagicon|UK}} [[Arrows (British band)|The Arrows]]
* {{flagicon|USA}} [[Rick Rivets|The Brats]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cosmik.com/aa-october02/reviews/review_brats.html|title=Review - The Brats: Criminal Guitar|publisher=Cosmik.com|accessdate=2 January 2015}}</ref>
* {{flagicon|USA}} [[Cherry Vanilla]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.punkglobe.com/cherryvanillaandmanparrishreview1011.php|title=CHERRY VANILLA  And MAN PARRISH|publisher=Punkglobe.com|accessdate=2 January 2015}}</ref>
* {{flagicon|USA}} [[Cuddly Toys]]<ref>[http://www.the5uk.com/Music%20City/CUDDLY%20TOYS.htm] {{dead link|date=January 2015}}</ref>
* {{flagicon|UK}} [[David Bowie]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/david-bowie-p3753|title=David Bowie - Music Biography, Streaming Radio and Discography - AllMusic|author=Stephen Thomas Erlewine|work=AllMusic|accessdate=2 January 2015}}</ref>

[[Category:Gospel blues]]"

 ****** List of gospel musicians

b'{{main|Gospel music}}
{{Gospel music articles}}
This incomplete list is specifically for [[Christian music]] performers in the [[Gospel music]] genres who have either been very important to the genre, or have had a considerable amount of exposure, such as in the case of one that has been on a major label, but not limited to such. This list includes artists that perform in traditional gospel music genres such as [[Southern Gospel]], [[traditional black gospel]], [[progressive Southern gospel]], [[urban contemporary gospel]], [[Gospel blues]], [[Christian country music]], Celtic gospel and British black gospel as well as artists in the [[music industry|general market]] who have recorded music in these genres. This list is not designed to include performers in the greater [[Christian music industry]] specifically [[contemporary Christian music]] performers and its subgenres.

Bands are listed by the first letter in their name (not including the words "a", "an", or "the"), and individuals are listed by [[family name]].

Note: Because classifying gospel music can be arbitrary, these groupings are generalized and many artists appear on multiple lists.

[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|H]]
[[Category:Harmonica blues musicians]]'

 ****** List of hardcore punk bands

b"{{category see also|Hardcore punk groups}}
This is a list of '''[[WP:BAND|notable bands]]''' considered to be [[hardcore punk]]. Hardcore punk (sometimes referred to simply as hardcore) is an underground music genre that originated in the late 1970s, following the mainstream success of punk rock. Hardcore is generally faster, thicker, and heavier than earlier punk rock.

__NOTOC__
{{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}

* [[100 Demons]]
* [[25 ta Life]]
* [[50 Lions]]
* [[7 Seconds (band)|7 Seconds]]
* [[88 Fingers Louie]]

 ****** List of heavy metal bands

b'This is a list of [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] artists from the first fourteen years of the movement. For bands that formed after 1981, please consult the [[#See also|lists for each heavy metal subgenre.]]
<!-- Please do not add bands which formed after 1981 to this list. Thankyou. -->

{{Compact ToC|center=yes|symnum=yes|seealso=yes|nobreak=yes}}

==Original movement: 1967\xe2\x80\x931981==
In the late 1960s a number of bands began pushing the limits of [[blues rock]] into a new genre which would be called heavy metal.<ref>
Weinstein, Deena. \'\'Heavy Metal: The Music and its Culture\'\'. DaCapo, 2000. ISBN 0-306-80970-2, pg. 14.
</ref><ref>
{{cite book |last=Christe |first=Ian |title=Sound of the Beast |publisher=Allison & Busby |isbn=0-7490-8351-4 |pages=1 |year=2004}}
</ref>

In 1981,<ref>http://80music.about.com/od/80smusic12/tp/1981moments.htm 1981 Snapshots in Music from About.com Web Guide</ref> three of the \'Big Four\' [[Thrash metal]] bands emerged: [[Metallica]],<ref>http://www.kerrang.com/wheretostartwith/artists/metallica Profile of Metallica at www.kerrang.com</ref> [[Slayer]]<ref>http://www.answers.com/topic/slayer-1 Profile of Slayer at Answers.com</ref> and [[Anthrax (American band)|Anthrax]];<ref>http://www.answers.com/topic/anthrax-artist Profile of Anthrax at Answers.com</ref> to be joined on the scene in 1983 by [[Megadeth]].<ref>http://www.lyricsfreak.com/m/megadeth/back+in+the+day_10177974.html "The world of metal changed forever..." - autiobiographical Megadeth lyrics at LyricsFreak website</ref>

<!-- N.B. Heavy metal bands which formed after 1981 are listed elsewhere on Wikipedia according to subgenre. -->

Alcohol abuse led to Ozzy Osbourne getting fired and replaced with former [[Rainbow (English band)|Rainbow]] vocalist [[Ronnie James Dio]]. Black Sabbath is considered to be the progenitor of [[doom metal]].

|[[Iron Maiden]]
|[[United Kingdom]]
|1975\xe2\x80\x93present
| Iron Maiden achieved success during the early 1980s. After several line-up changes, the band went on to release a series of U.S. and UK platinum and gold albums, including 1982\'s \'\'[[The Number of the Beast]]\'\', 1983\'s \'\'[[Piece of Mind]]\'\', 1984\'s \'\'[[Powerslave]]\'\', 1985\'s live release \'\'[[Live After Death]]\'\', 1986\'s \'\'[[Somewhere in Time]]\'\' and 1988\'s \'\'[[Seventh Son of a Seventh Son]]\'\'.

 ****** List of indie pop artists

b'This is a list of [[indie pop]] artists who have either been important to the genre or have had a considerable amount of exposure (such as in the case of one that has been on a major label, but not limited to such). This list does not include little-known local bands. Bands are listed by the first letter in their name (not including the words "a", "an", or "the"), and individuals are listed by last name.

 ****** List of industrial music bands

b'This is a list of notable bands that play [[industrial music]], or have been described as playing such at some point in their careers.

<!-- Please help keep the list isolated to IDM musicians! Nearly every genre has its own list. Search for the right list, leave this one alone. :)

*******DO:
...Add notable musicians whose releases are primarily classified as IDM.
...Include notable multi-genre musicians with significant releases classified as IDM (i.e. More IDM releases than not)
...Only include notable musicians WITH A WIKIPEDIA ARTICLE!
...Create new articles for IDM musicians who meet the Wikipedia notability guidelines, THEN add them to this list.
...Add non-IDM musicians to the lists for their relevant genre(s) (tip: search Wikipedia)
...Remember to brush your teeth.

*******DO NOT:
...Include musicians who aren\'t generally considered as IDM artists (tip: check discogs).
...Add non-notable musicians, per Wikipedia\'s notability guidelines. (These musicians probably shouldn\'t have articles, anyway.)
...Include notable IDM musicians without a Wikipedia article!
...Create new articles for a IDM musicians who don\'t meet the notability requirements.
...Add notable musicians who you, personally, think "sounds like IDM". (again, check discogs)
...Delete this commented section without first discussing it on the article\'s Talk page.
...Forget to brush your teeth.

-->

[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre]]
[[Category:Intelligent dance musicians|*]]'

 ****** List of J-pop artists

b'__NOTOC__
This is a list of [[J-pop]] artist and groups. Originally an evolution of [[Jazz]], and coined New Music, the style went on to become known as City Pop; music with an urban theme. Later called [[Japan]]-made Pop, the term was shortened to J-pop and now encompasses a wide range of musical styles and [[Music genre|genres]]. J-pop represents modern [[pop culture]] music originating from the country or musical talent of Japan.

{{Dynamic list}}

{{Compact ToC|side=yes|nobreak=yes|center=yes|symnum=yes|seealso=yes}}

 ****** List of Japanoise artists

b'{{about|artists of a musical genre|renowned artists of Japanese nationality|List of Japanese artists}}
{{refimprove|date=January 2008}}
This is an alphabetical list of Japanese noise, or "[[Japanoise]]" (\xe3\x82\xb8\xe3\x83\xa3\xe3\x83\x91\xe3\x83\x8e\xe3\x82\xa4\xe3\x82\xba) bands and solo projects that have articles on Wikipedia.

 ****** List of Latin freestyle musicians and songs

b'[[Freestyle music|Latin freestyle]] is a form of American [[electronic dance music]] of  [[electro-funk]], [[post-disco]], [[Italo disco]], [[hip hop|hip-hop]] origins, that is popular within Latino communities. This is a list of notable [[freestyle music|freestyle]] music groups, musicians, songs and albums.

{| border="0" align="center" class="toccolours"
|-
! {{MediaWiki:Toc}}
|-
| align="center" | [[#Examples of musicians|Artists]] \xe2\x80\xa2 [[#History|History]] ([[#1980s|1980s]] \xe2\x80\xa2 [[#1990s|1990s]]) \xe2\x80\xa2 [[#Examples of albums|Albums]] \xe2\x80\xa2 [[#Compilations|Compilations]] \xe2\x80\xa2 [[#References|References]]
 __NOTOC__
|}

 ****** List of lovers rock artists

b'This is a list of [[lovers rock]] [[musician|artists]]. This includes artists who have either been very important to the genre, or have had a considerable amount of exposure (such as in the case of one that has been on a major label, but not limited to such). Groups are listed by the first letter in their name (not including the words "a", "an", or "the"), and individuals are listed by last name.<!--Please add new entries in alphabetical order-->

 ****** List of maritime music performers

b'This is a list of performers who focus on maritime music or who have at some point made notable contributions to that genre.
==Traditional-style performers==

*[[Jerry Bryant (songwriter)|Jerry Bryant]], singer-songwriter from Maine, also performs historical shanties in a traditional style.
*[[Johnny Collins]], a modern-day shantyman (1938\xe2\x80\x932009).<!--[What made him a modern day shantyman any more than others?]-->
*[[Forebitter]], group featuring performers associated with the Mystic Seaport Museum.
*[[Stan Hugill]], "Last Working Shantyman" (1906\xe2\x80\x931992).
*[[The Idlers]], an all-male \'\'a cappella\'\' shanty group at the [[United States Coast Guard Academy]] (1957\xe2\x80\x93present)
*[[The Johnson Girls]], an all-female shanty group from New York.
*[[Tom and Chris Kastle]], singer-songwriters from Chicago, also perform historical shanties in a traditional style.
*[[Tom Lewis (songwriter)|Tom Lewis]], Canadian singer-songwriter, also performs historical shanties in a traditional style.
*[[Northern Neck Shanty Singers|Northern Neck Chantey Singers]], a menhaden shanty group, some of whom learned the songs as work songs on fishing boats when they were young men.<ref>http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/01/19/assignment_america/main2378720.shtml</ref>
*[[Roberts and Barrand]], proponents of traditional British song from New York and New England (1969-)
*[[Salty Walt & the Rattlin\' Ratlines]], from San Francisco.

==Folk music-style performers==
*[[Peter Bellamy]], British folk singer. (1944-1981).  Wrote "Roll Down" (aka "Transports Shanty").
*[[Debra Cowan]], sea music performer from Shrewsbury, Massachusetts.
*[[Roger McGuinn]], from Chicago.
*[[William Pint and Felicia Dale]], from Seattle.
*[[Bob Roberts (folksinger)|Bob Roberts]], British Merchant Seaman and folk singer (1907\xe2\x80\x931982)
*[[Stan Rogers]], Canadian performer (1949\xe2\x80\x931983), wrote "[[Barrett\'s Privateers]]".
*[[Cyril Tawney]], British performer (1930\xe2\x80\x932005).
*[[John Townley]], also known for opening the first 12-track recording studio in New York, [[Apostolic Studios]].
*[[Bob Zentz]]


==Contemporary-style performers==
*[[Banana Boat]], an \'\'[[a cappella]]\'\' sextet from [[Poland]] performing "neo-shanties" as well as traditional sea-shanties in contemporary arrangements.
*[[Bounding Main]], an \'\'[[a cappella]]\'\' quintet based near [[Kenosha, Wisconsin]].
*[[Captain Bogg and Salty]], a [[Piracy|pirate]]-themed rock band which performs many traditional shanties, as well as writing several of their own.
*[[Great Big Sea]], Canadian band performing some shanties in traditional style.
*[[The Jolly Rogers]], a modern-day pirate-themed band and comedy performance group.
*[[Jon Campbell (songwriter)|Jon Campbell]], composer of nautically-themed folk songs including \'\'Tanqueray Martini-O!\'\' which was often performed by Johnny Collins.

==See also==
*[[Sea shanty]]
*[[Folk music]]
*[[List of maritime music festivals]]

==References==
{{reflist}}

[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Maritime music performers]]
[[Category:Maritime music]]'

 ****** List of mathcore bands

b'{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}}
This is a list of [[mathcore]] bands in [[alphabetical order]]. Note that this list includes bands that have at some point in their careers either played mathcore, or in similar terms to its original sound. Some of these bands may also be classed as progressive metalcore.
