 ****** List of merengue musicians

b'List of merengue musicians is a list of notable musicians who do [[merengue music]].

==Dominican and Caribbean==
*[[Aguakate]]
*[[Amarfis]]
*[[Elvis Crespo]] - Winner at the [[Latin Grammy Awards of 2005]] for Merengue album,
*[[Fulanito]]
*[[Fefita La Grande]]
*[[Juan Espinola]]
*[[Juan Luis Guerra]]
*[[Ricardo Gutierrez]]
*[[Tatico Henriquez]]
*[[Julio Alberto Hernandez]]
*[[Eddy Herrera]] - Nominee at the [[Latin Grammy Awards of 2006]] for merengue album.
*[[La India Canela]]
*[[Kerube]]
*[[Krisspy]]
*[[Limi-T 21]] - Nominee at the [[Latin Grammy Awards of 2006]] for merengue album.
*[[Los Toros Band]] - Nominee at the [[Latin Grammy Awards of 2005]] and [[Lo Nuestro Awards]] for merengue album.<ref name="Los Toros Band">{{cite web| url = http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/2004/12/2/univision_announces_premio_lo_nuestro_2005.htm | title = Univision Announces \xe2\x80\x98Premio Lo Nuestro\xe2\x80\x99 2005 Nominees  | author = Hispanic PR Wire | date = 2 December 2004 | work = | publisher  = HispanicBusiness.com | accessdate = 11 November 2012}}</ref>
*[[\xc3\x91ico Lora]]
*[[Grupo Mania]] - Nominee at the [[Latin Grammy Awards of 2006]] for merengue album.
*[[Kinito Mendez]] - Nominee at the [[Latin Grammy Awards of 2005]] for merengue album.
*[[Omega]]
*[[Ram\xc3\xb3n Orlando]]
*[[Chichi Peralta]] - Winner of [[Latin Grammy Awards of 2001]] for merengue album.
*[[Geovanny Polanco]]
*[[El Prodigio]]
*[[Milly Quezada]] - Winner in the [[Latin Grammy Awards of 2003]], dubbed "Queen of Merengue."
*[[Raul Roman]]
*[[To\xc3\xb1o Rosario]]
*[[Francisco Ulloa (accordionist)|Francisco Ulloa]]
*[[Cuco Valoy]]
*[[Sergio Vargas]]
*[[Wilfrido Vargas]]
*[[Johnny Ventura]] - Winner of [[Latin Grammy Awards of 2004]] for merengue album.
*[[Fernando Villalona]]

==Venezuelan merengue==
*[[Los Ca\xc3\xb1oneros]]

[[Category:Merengue musicians|*]]'

 ****** List of metalcore bands

b'<!---Please only add bands with articles to this list--->
[[Metalcore]] is a broad fusion genre of [[extreme metal]] and [[hardcore punk]]. Its subgenres include [[mathcore]] and [[melodic metalcore]], while (especially older) metalcore leaning towards hardcore is sometimes labelled "metallic hardcore". This incomplete list includes bands described as performing any of these styles (including in combination with other styles), but does not list [[deathcore]] bands, which fuse metalcore with [[death metal]], or [[electronicore]] bands, which fuse metalcore with [[post-hardcore]] and [[electronic music]], as there is a separate list for both  [[List of deathcore artists|deathcore bands]] and [[Electronicore#List_of_artists|electronicore bands]]. There is also an additional [[list of mathcore bands]].

<!---Please only add bands with articles to this list--->

[[Category:Lists of heavy metal bands]]'

 ****** List of new-age music artists

b'This is a list of new-age music artists with articles on Wikipedia.

[[New-age music]] is broadly defined as relaxing, even "meditative", music that is primarily instrumental. Unlike relaxing forms of classical music, New-age music makes greater use of electronica and non-Western instrumentation. There is some debate on what can be considered "new-age music"; for example several musicians in [[Celtic music]] or [[Smooth jazz]] have expressed annoyance at being labeled "new-age musicians". For more on that debate, see the article on [[new-age music]]. In addition, several musicians object to the label because they fear it implies a connection to the [[New Age]] movement.

{{Compact ToC}}

 ****** List of new jack swing artists

b'{{refimprove|article|date=October 2011}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}}
This list contains singers and bands from 1984 to 1997 who performed in the [[new jack swing]] style, a [[Cross-genre|hybrid]] style popular from the mid-1980s into the early-to-mid-1990s, which fuses the [[rhythm]]s, [[sampling (music)|samples]] and production techniques of [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] and [[dance-pop]] music with the [[urban contemporary]] sound of [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]. The new jack swing style developed as many previous R&B styles did, by combining elements of older styles with newer trends. It uses mellifluously soulful [[Solo (music)|solo]] or harmonizing vocals sung over rhythms and "street" beats derived from urban musical influences. The sound of new jack swing comes from the hip hop "swing" beats created by [[drum machine]], and hardware samplers, which was popular during the [[Golden age hip hop|golden age of hip hop]], with [[contemporary R&B]] style singing.

==1984\xe2\x80\x931989==
Successful records to influence the rise of [[new jack swing]] by creating a fusion of R&B, rap, funk, disco and synthesized percussion.<ref>{{cite book|first= Richard J. |last= Ripani |title= The New Blue Music: Changes in Rhythm & Blues, 1950\xe2\x80\x931999 |publisher= [[University Press of Mississippi]] |year= 2006 |pages= 130\xe2\x80\x93153 |isbn= 1-57806-862-2}}.</ref>

Sure! : Biography |first= Steve |last= Huey |work= [[AllMusic|Allmusic]] |publisher= [[Rovi Corporation]] |quote= During the late \'80s, Al B. Sure! enjoyed a brief run as one of new jack swing\'s most popular romantic singers. |accessdate= 6 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="NBM"/>

[[Category:Rhythm and blues]]
[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|New Jack Swing]]
[[Category:Lists of hip hop musicians|New Jack Swing]]'

 ****** List of new wave artists and bands

b'{{consensus| There is no consensus for whether early alternative rock or post-punk are subgenres of new wave and thus whether acts associated with these genres belong on this list. There is also no consensus if first-wave punk rock acts circa 1976\xe2\x80\x931978 belong on this list nor sourcing criteria and level of notoriety needed for list inclusion. - See talk pages|date=January 2013}}
{{Main|New wave music}}
The following is a list of music acts that began late 1970s through the middle 1980s that were new wave acts or had some elements of the genre in their music.

Individual members of new wave groups are not listed unless their solo work has had elements of new wave music. Band members often work on solo projects because they want to explore different music styles. Also not listed are acts associated with the resurgences and revivals of the genre that have occurred from the 1990s onward. Acts associated with these revivals are found in the [[List of post-punk revival bands]] article.

Groups and artists with aliases are listed by the first letter in their name, and individuals are listed by their surname.

<!-- As well sourced in the main article conventional wisdom among reliable sources holds that new wave ended after mid 1980s. Artists who started after this will be deleted. To change this go to talk page and try and form a consensus to add these. -->
<!-- Reminder YouTube can not be used as source. The source is whomever created the youtube channel thus inherently unreliable. Even if a reliable organization created the channel there are copyright issues. -->
<!-- No need to make this list longer by adding every member of each act listed unless they have reliably sourced solo new wave work. See talk page -->
<!--- If a group is not basically a new wave group but has an element of new wave music, list the album and period when they were new wave -->

New wave artists and bands:
{{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}

[[Category:Noise musicians|*]]"

 ****** List of nu metal bands

b'The following is a list of [[nu metal]] bands that have been described as members of the genre by professional journalists at some stage in their career.

  | last = McIver

* [[Walter Dana]] polka promoter and founder of Dana Records
* [[El\xc3\xa4kel\xc3\xa4iset]]
* [[Myron Floren]]
* [[FreezeDried]]
* [[Global Kryner]], Austrian band/pop/jazz/polka
* [[Romy Gosz]]
* [[Walt Groller]]
* [[Happy Louie and Julcia\'s Polka Band]]
* [[Haunted Cologne]]
* [[Walter Jagiello]] - [[Li\'l Wally]]
* [[The Knewz]] 
* [[Harold Loeffelmacher]], Dutchman/Oompah
* [[Loituma]]
* [[Walter Ostanek]], [[Canada]],  three-time [[Grammy Award]] winner, Slovenian-Canadian
* [[Polkacide]], San Francisco punk-polka band
* [[Polkaholix|POLKAHOLIX]] (Berlin Speed Polka) (Germany)
* [[The Mike Schneider Polka Band]], [[Slovenian-style polka]] band from [[Milwaukee, WI]]<ref>{{cite web | work=WisconsinPolkaMusic.com | url=http://www.wisconsinpolkamusic.com/bandlist.html| title=Wisconsin Polka Bands| accessdate= 2009-07-01}}</ref>
* [[Six Fat Dutchmen]]
* [[Walt Solek]], the "Clown Prince of Polka"
* [[Jimmy Sturr]], [[United States]], eighteen [[Grammy Award]]s
* [[Lawrence Welk]]
* [[Whoopee John Wilfahrt]]
* [["Weird Al" Yankovic]] (Every studio album except his self-titled debut and "[[Even Worse]]" has a polka [[Medley_%28music%29|medley]] on it of popular music)
* [[Frankie Yankovic]], Slovenian-American

 ****** List of psych folk artists

b'Following is a list of psych folk artists.  [[Psychedelic folk]] or psych folk is a loosely defined form of [[psychedelic music]] that originated in the 1960s through the fusion of  [[folk music]] and [[psychedelic rock]]. It retained the largely acoustic instrumentation of folk, but added musical influences common to psychedelic rock and the [[psychedelic experience]]. The term only evolved in the 2000s (decade).

 ****** List of pipe bands

b"[[File:Pipe band in the Lawnmarket, Edinburgh.jpg|thumb|280px|Scottish pipe band marching in Edinburgh]]
A '''[[pipe band]]''' is a musical ensemble consisting of [[Bagpipes|pipers]] and [[marching percussion|drummers]]. There are many such bands in the world, which play for ceremonial purposes, recreation, [[Pipe band#Competition .26 The World Pipe Band Championships|competition]] or all three. This list encompasses only notable pipe bands with their own Wikipedia page.

==North America Pipe Band Associations==
*[[British Columbia Pipers Association]] (BCPA), Pipe Band Association for British Columbia, Washington, and Oregon.  Home of the 2008 World Champion [[Simon Fraser University Pipe Band]].
*[[Eastern United States Pipe Band Association]] (EUSPBA), the Eastern US equivalent of the RSPBA.
*[[Midwest Pipe Band Association]] (MWPBA), pipe band association encompassing the Midwest region.
*[[Southern United States Pipe Band Association]] (SUSPBA), an association primarily of pipe bands from [[Florida]].
*[[Western United States Pipe Band Association]] (WUSPBA), the pipe band association of the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]].

==European Pipe Band Associations==
*[[Royal Scottish Pipe Band Association]] \xe2\x80\x94 Possibly the most important administrative organization in the pipe band world, the RSPBA organizes the World Pipe Band Championships as well as all other competitions in [[Scotland]].

===Belgium===
* [[Antwerp & District Pipe Band]] ([[Antwerp]])

===Northern Ireland===
*[[Aughintober Pipe Band]] ([[Castlecaulfield]])
*[[Field Marshal Montgomery Pipe Band]] ([[Lisburn]])
*[[Ballycoan Pipe Band]] ([[Belfast]])

===Republic of Ireland===
* [[St. Laurence O'Toole Pipe Band]] ([[Dublin, Ireland|Dublin]])

===Scotland===
[[File:Pipe band, Castlehill Edinburgh.JPG|thumb|280px|Pipe band on Castlehill, [[Edinburgh]]]]
*[[Boghall and Bathgate Caledonia Pipe Band]] ([[West Lothian]])
*[[Clan Gregor Society Pipe Band]] ([[Falkirk]])
*[[Deeside Caledonia Pipe Band]] ([[Aberdeen]])
*[[Denny and Dunipace Pipe Band]] ([[Denny, Falkirk]])
*[[Dysart and Dundonald Pipe Band]] ([[Fife]])
*[[Greater Glasgow Police Scotland Pipe Band]] ([[Glasgow]])

 ****** List of post-disco artists and songs

b'{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}}
The term [[post-disco]] is a referral to the early to late 1980s era movement of [[disco]] music into more stripped-down [[Electronic music|electronic]] [[funk]] influenced sounds; post-disco was also predecessor to [[house music]].

This chronological list contains examples of artists, songs and albums described as [[post-disco]], as well as its subgenre, [[Boogie (genre)|boogie]].
{|border="0" align="center" class="toccolours"
!{{MediaWiki:Toc}}
|-
|align="center"|[[#Artists|Some artists]]: [[#A|A]] [[#B|B]] [[#C|C]] [[#D|D]] [[#E|E]] [[#F|F]] [[#G|G]] [[#I|I]] [[#J|J]] [[#K|K]] [[#L|L]] [[#M|M]] [[#N|N]] [[#O|O]] [[#P|P]] [[#R|R]] [[#S|S]] [[#U|U]] [[#W|W]] [[#Y|Y]] [[#Z|Z]]<br>[[#Songs|Some songs]]: [[#Late 1970s|Late 1970s]] \xe2\x80\xa2 [[#Early 1980s|Early 1980s]] \xe2\x80\xa2 [[#Mid to late 1980s|Mid to late 1980s]] \xe2\x80\xa2 [[#2000s and 2010s|2000s and 2010s]]<br>[[#Albums|Some albums]]
__NOTOC__
|}

[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Post-disco]]
[[Category:Post-disco| ]]'

 ****** List of post-dubstep musicians

b'{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}}
This is a list of [[post-dubstep]] musicians. This includes artists who have either been very important to the genre or have had a considerable amount of exposure (such as in the case of one that has been on a major label, but not limited to such). This list does not include little-known local artists.

==List==
{{colbegin|2}}
*[[Chase & Status]]<ref name="PD">{{cite journal|first= Charles |last= Aaron |title= LISTEN: 10 Post-Dubstep Artists Who Matter |magazine= [[Spin (magazine)|Spin]] |url= http://www.spin.com/articles/listen-10-post-dubstep-artists-who-matter/ |date= 14 March 2011 |accessdate= 11 November 2013}}</ref>
*[[Darkstar (band)|Darkstar]]<ref name="PD"/><ref>{{cite web|first= Alex |last= Denney |title= Darkstar \xe2\x80\x93 \'News From Nowhere\' |work= [[NME]] |publisher= [[IPC Media]] |date= 31 January 2013 |url= http://www.nme.com/reviews/darkstar/14029 |accessdate= 11 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Music: Darkstar |newspaper= [[The Stool Pigeon (newspaper)|The Stool Pigeon]] |date= 16 January 2013 |accessdate= 11 November 2013 |url= http://www.thestoolpigeon.co.uk/features/music-darkstar-stream-news-from-nowhere.html}}</ref>
*[[Flux Pavilion]]<ref name="PD"/>

[[All Media Network]] |accessdate= 25 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.musicomh.com/reviews/albums/mount-kimbie-cold-spring-fault-less-youth |first= Christopher |last= Monk |title= Mount Kimbie \xe2\x80\x93 Cold Spring Fault Less Youth |publisher= [[musicOMH]] |date= 21 May 2013 |accessdate= 25 October 2014}}</ref>
*[[Nero (band)|Nero]]<ref name="PD"/>
*[[Scuba (musician)|Scuba]]<ref name="PD"/>

*[[XXYYXX]]<ref>{{cite web|first= Franc |last= Sayol |title= XXYYXX: "I\'m Just A Brat With A Laptop And A MIDI Controller" |publisher= PlayGround |url= http://www.playgroundmag.net/music/music-magazine-articles/music-interviews/xxyyxx-im-just-a-brat-with-a-laptop-and-a-midi-controller |date= 16 July 2012 |accessdate= 11 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first= Scott |last= Taft |title= XXYYXX Outdoes Debut Album With A More Minimal Follow-Up |publisher= Off Kilter Future Music |url= http://offkiltermusic.com/minimal/xxyyxx-outdoes-debut-album-with-a-more-minimal-follow-up/ |date= 3 April 2012 |accessdate= 11 November 2013}}</ref>

He was arguably the least \'post\' of the post-dubstep artists. |publisher= [[Faber and Faber]] |year= 2013 |isbn= 978-0-5712-8914-1}}</ref>

 ****** List of power pop artists and songs

b'<!-- All entries MUST be sourced.
     Unsourced entries will be removed.
     If the entry doesn\'t have an article, please link it with an appropriate existing article (e.g. the album on which the song appears, the artist\'s article,...), except for albums (but a reference is required anyway).
     HOWEVER, PLEASE DO NOT ADD AN ARTIST FOR WHICH THERE IS ABSOLUTELY NO ARTICLE AT ALL !
     If you intend to use a reference several times, please add it at the bottom of this page, under the section "References", and please respect the alphabetical order regarding references names. Thank you very much. -->
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}}
[[Power pop]] is a music genre which borrows elements from [[hard rock]] and [[Pop music|pop]]. Although its mainstream success peaked in the late 1970s and early 1980s, the genre continues to influence new artists.<ref name="Sunday"/>

The following list is divided in three sections. The first section includes notable power pop bands and solo artists. The second section includes chronologically listed power pop albums. The third section features power pop songs by power pop artists, as well as power pop songs by artists whose main music genre is not power pop. Solo artists are listed alphabetically by last name, and groups are listed alphabetically by the first letter (not including the prefix "the", "a" or "an").

{|border="0" align="center" class="toccolours"

===J===
{{div col|colwidth=30em}}

*[[Sue Keller]], (1952-)

*[[Bob Milne]]

 ****** List of reggae fusion artists

b'This is a list of [[reggae fusion|reggae fusion artists]]. This includes artists who <u>have either been very important to the genre</u>, or have had a <u>considerable amount of exposure</u> (such as in the case of one that has been on a major label, but not limited to such). Bands are listed by the first letter in their name (not including the words "a", "an", or "the"), and individuals are listed by last name.

 ****** List of riot grrrl bands

b'{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}}
The following is a list of bands \'\'associated\'\' with the [[riot grrrl]] genre from the early 1990s to the present, mainly in the [[United States|USA]] and [[United Kingdom|UK]].

NB: some of these bands pre-dated the original riot grrrl movement (e.g. Frightwig, Fifth Column, Mecca Normal, Scrawl), while others may be more accurately categorised as [[grunge]] - see also \'[[foxcore]]\' - (e.g. L7, Babes in Toyland, Calamity Jane), [[queercore]] (e.g. Tribe 8, The Need), [[Punk rock|punk]] (e.g. Spitboy), [[post punk]]/[[no wave]] (e.g. Erase Errata, Scissor Girls), [[digital hardcore]] (Lolita Storm), [[alternative rock]] (e.g. Autoclave), [[pop punk]] (e.g. Bangs, Angelica) or [[indie pop]] (e.g. Shrag). 

Many bands did not identify with riot grrrl during the scene\'s first wave of the early 1990s but became associated via personal and artistic connections (e.g. 7 Year Bitch), or identified as riot grrrl by fans and/or the media due to aesthetic and genre similarities (e.g. Hole, The Gits). On the same basis bands continue to be identified or self-identify as riot grrrl up to the present day. Therefore the label is partially \'\'subjective\'\', and often disputed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/features/articles/8710-not-every-girl-is-a-riot-grrrl/|title=Articles|work=Pitchfork}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2014/06/album-review-white-lung-deep-fantasy/|title=White Lung \xe2\x80\x93 Deep Fantasy - Album Reviews - Consequence of Sound|work=Consequence of Sound}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://screamingfemales.blogspot.co.uk/2007/02/wiki-riot-grrrl.html|title=SCREAMING FEMALES: Wiki -Riot Grrrl|work=screamingfemales.blogspot.co.uk}}</ref>

 ****** List of shoegazing musicians

b'{{Refimprove|date=February 2011}}
The following is a list of shoegazing musicians, i.e., musicians who play in the [[shoegazing]] style:<!--Unsourced additions may be removed-->

{{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}

==Third wave ska (starting in early 1980s)==
<!--Only add bands with Wikipedia articles showing they play primarily ska. Only add bands that are famous or influential. Add new bands in alphabetical order.-->
{{main|Third wave ska}}
{{colbegin|4}}
*[[Against All Authority]]
*[[Allniters]]
*[[Animal Chin]]
*[[The Aquabats]]
*[[Area-7]]
*[[The Arrogant Sons of Bitches]]

*[[B. Lee Band]]
*[[Blue Meanies (Illinois band)|Blue Meanies]]
*[[Big D and the Kids Table]]

[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Ska]]
[[Category:Ska musicians]]'

 ****** List of soft rock artists and songs

b'The following is a list of notable [[soft rock]] bands and artists and their most notable soft rock songs. This list should not include artists whose main style of music is anything other than soft rock, even if they have released one or more songs that fall under the "soft rock" genre. (Such songs can be added under [[:Category:Soft rock songs]].)

Artists which have released music of various different genres throughout their career including soft rock as one of their main styles, may be included together with their notable soft rock songs.

<!-- DO NOT ADD ARTISTS WHOSE MAIN STYLE OF MUSIC IS NOT SOFT ROCK,

EVEN IF THEY HAVE RELEASED ONE OR MORE SONGS THAT FALL UNDER THE "SOFT ROCK" GENRE.

RATHER, THOSE SONGS CAN BE ADDED (IF SUCH AN ARTICLE EXISTS) UNDER Category:Soft rock songs.

ARTISTS THAT HAVE RELEASED MUSIC OF VARIOUS OTHER GENRES DURING THEIR CAREER

BUT WERE ONCE A SOFT ROCK ACT RELEASING SOFT ROCK SONGS, MAY BE INCLUDED.

ALL ENTRIES MUST HAVE ARTICLES AND MUST BE SOURCED -->

[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Soft rock]]
[[Category:Lists of songs|Soft rock]]
[[Category:Soft rock| ]]'

 ****** List of soul musicians

b'{{refimprove|date=June 2014}}
This is a list of [[soul music]]ians who have either been influential within the genre, or have had a considerable amount of fame. Bands are listed by the first letter in their name (not including the words "a", "an", or "the"), and individuals are listed by last name.

{{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}
__NOTOC__

{{Soulmusic}}

[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Soul]]
[[Category:Soul music| ]]'

 ****** List of surf musicians

b"This is a '''list of surf musicians'''. [[Surf music]] is a [[genre]] of [[popular music]] associated with [[surf culture]], particularly as found in [[Orange County, California|Orange County]] and other areas of [[Southern California]]. It was especially popular from 1961 to 1966, has subsequently been revived and was highly influential on subsequent [[rock music]].<ref name=Bogdanov2002Surf>V. Bogdanov, C. Woodstra and S. T. Erlewine, ''All music guide to rock: the definitive guide to rock, pop, and soul'' (Backbeat Books, 3rd edn., 2002), pp. 1313-4.</ref>

[[Category:Lists of musicians by genre|Surf]]
[[Category:Surf musicians| ]]
[[Category:Surf music groups| ]]"

 ****** List of synthpop artists

b'{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}}
[[Synthpop]] (also known as electropop or technopop) is a pop music genre that uses the [[synthesizer]] as the dominant musical instrument. With the genre becoming popular in the 1980s, the following article is a list of notable Synthpop acts, not including those that do just [[dance-pop]] music. listed by the first letter in their name (not including articles such as "a", "an", or "the"). Individuals are listed by last name.
<!--
RULES AND INFORMATION ABOUT ADDING ARTISTS AND BANDS TO THIS LIST:

Just because an act uses synthesizers does not mean they are necessarily a synthpop act. Synthpop is a subgenre of electronic music. There are many sub genres of electronic music some of whom are very different from synthpop. Most dance-pop acts since the 2000s have used synths leading to significant overlap of dance-pop and synthpop/electropop genres. This has lead to a widespread false perception that the genres are synonymous.

DO NOT ADD AN ENTRY UNLESS THE WIKIPEDIA ARTICLE FOR THE ACT STATES THAT THE BAND/ARTIST IS IN THE SYNTHPOP GENRE AND THE ARTICLE USES RELIABLE SOURCES TO BACK UP THEIR CLAIM THAT THE BAND/ARTIST IS SYNTHPOP. THIS IS TO PREVENT ORIGINAL RESEARCH (See WP:OR). This list is audited daily to remove original research entries/vandalism.

If you see the color red for an entry after you add it that means that there has been no Wikipedia article written for that music act and therefore it can not be entered. Sometimes this happens because of a misspelling or a lower case letter is used instead of an upper case. At other times the act is just not notable to be included in this list and at other times editors have just not gotten around to creating an article for that act. If you believe an act should be added to this list but no Wikipedia article has been written for them you have two choices. You may create an article for the act yourself and then add it to this list. Or you may go to the talk page and request we do it.

Thank you.
-->

{{compact ToC}}
{{dynamic list|date=January 2013}}

|first= Dan |last= LeRoy |publisher= AllMusic. All Media Network |accessdate= 6 October 2013 |quote= But the thoughtful, Tears for Fears-style synth pop of the debut is replaced here by a more generic AOR approach}}</ref>

[[Category:Synthpop musicians| ]]'

 ****** List of tango singers

b'This is a list of notable tango singers, that is, notable [[singer]]s who are accomplished in the [[Tango music|tango]] genre. Many tango musicians have been both [[musician]]s and singers, but this does not exclude from this list. While the vast majority of earlier tango singers were [[Argentina|Argentines]], this list illustrates the diversification of tango over time, with the growth in female stars such as [[Susana Rinaldi]] and the spread of tango around the world, as far as [[Russia]] ([[Pyotr Leshchenko]]), [[Poland]] ([[Jerzy Petersburski]]), and [[Turkey]] ([[\xc4\xb0brahim \xc3\x96zg\xc3\xbcr]]).

<!--IMPORTANT NOTICE: If adding entries from a list of notable tango singers (reliable sources only), use note-referencing as seen in the "source lists" section. If adding entries individually, include a summary that asserts their notability as a tango singer and reference using cite.php. All members of this list should fulfil the WP:MUSIC criteria specifically for their work in tango, and as singers not just instrumentalists. All other entries should be removed.-->

{{dynamic list}}

==A==

*[[Alberto Acu\xc3\xb1a]]{{Ref_label|tango.info|TI|none}} {{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}} {{flagicon|Argentina}} (1896-1975) from [[Buenos Aires]], formed a famous duo with [[Ren\xc3\xa9 Ruiz]] and was also a guitar player and composer.<ref>Orlando del Greco, \'\'[http://www.todotango.com/english/creadores/aacuna.html Alberto Acu\xc3\xb1a]\'\', todotango.com. URL accessed 12 July 2006</ref>
*[[Carlos Acu\xc3\xb1a]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}  {{Ref_label|tango.info|TI|none}} {{flagicon|Argentina}} (1915-1999) was known for his deep, high and expressive voice. His foreign travels brought him success in [[Uruguay]], [[Mexico]], [[Italy]] and [[Spain]], where he became a close friend of the exiled [[Juan Per\xc3\xb3n]].<ref>Jorge Palacio, \'\'[http://www.todotango.com/english/creadores/cacuna.asp Carlos Acu\xc3\xb1a]\'\', todotango.com. URL accessed 12 July 2006</ref>
*[[Eduardo Adri\xc3\xa1n]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}} {{flagicon|Argentina}} (1923-1989) from [[Mar del Plata]] was also a writer, lecturer and theater director.<ref>N\xc3\xa9stor Pins\xc3\xb3n, \'\'[http://www.todotango.com/english/creadores/eadrian.asp Eduardo Adri\xc3\xa1n]\'\', todotango.com. URL accessed 12 July 2006</ref>\t\t
*[[Carlos Almada]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t\t
*[[Oscar Alonso]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}
*[[Alberto Amor]]{{Ref_label|tango.info|TI|none}}
*[[Francisco Amor]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t\t
*[[Alberto Arenas]]{{Ref_label|tango.info|TI|none}} {{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t
*[[Imperio Argentina]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t\t
*[[Ernesto Ariel]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t\t
*[[Roberto Arrieta]]{{Ref_label|tango.info|TI|none}} {{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}

==H==

*[[Seyyan Hanim]] {{flagicon|Turkey}} (1913-1989) was a major figure of [[feminism|women\'s emancipation]] in [[Turkey]], taking advantage of [[Mustafa Kemal Atat\xc3\xbcrk|Atat\xc3\xbcrk]]\'s secularization (and personal protection) to become one of the earliest Muslim women to appear on stage there.<ref name=Turkey>Uli Schumann, \'\'[http://www.kidojo.it/tango/art013_en.html Turkish Tango : Seyyan Hanin and Ibrahim \xc3\x96zg\xc3\xbcr]\'\', kidojo.it (translated by E. Maresglia). URL accessed 13 July 2006</ref> Her singing repertoire also included [[Rumba (dance)|rumba]] and [[foxtrot]], but tango made her reputation, and she recorded the first [[Turkish language]] tango, [[Necip Celal]]\'s \'\'Mazi\'\' ("The Past") in 1932. She recorded around 50 [[gramophone record|LP]]s for [[HMV]] and several more for [[Odeon Records|Odeon]].<ref>Aydogan-Sule Arkis (2002), \'\'[http://www.tangointurkey.com/GalleryPages/Singers.htm Seyyan Hanim (Oskay 1913-1989)]\'\', tangointurkey.com. URL accessed 13 July 2006</ref>
*[[Carlos Heredia]]{{Ref_label|tango.info|TI|none}}

*[[Rodolfo Lesica]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t\t
*[[Pyotr Leshchenko]] {{flagicon|Russia}} (1898-1954) The "King of Russian Tango" enjoyed great popularity both in Russia and abroad despite being suppressed in the [[Soviet Union]]. He sang mainly in Russian, also singing [[Romani music|gypsy music]]. He died in a prison camp near [[Bucharest]].<ref>Uli Schumann, \'\'[http://www.kidojo.it/tango/art012_en.html Russian Tango : Pjotr Konstantinowitsch Leschenko]\'\', kidojo.it. URL accessed  13 July 2006</ref>

==N==

*[[Gustavo Nocetti]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}} {{flagicon|Uruguay}} (1959-2002)\t\t

==O==

*[[Quique Ojeda]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t\t
*[[Sabina Olmos]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t\t
*[[Jorge Omar]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t\t
*[[Nelly Omar]]{{Ref_label|tango.info|TI|none}} {{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}
*[[Jorge Ort\xc3\xadz (singer)|Jorge Ort\xc3\xadz]]{{Ref_label|tango.info|TI|none}} {{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}
*[[\xc4\xb0brahim \xc3\x96zg\xc3\xbcr]] {{flagicon|Turkey}} (1905-1959) was dubbed "The King of Turkish Tango" for his singing and composition, after an earlier successful career in [[jazz]]. He began tango recordings in 1938. His nostalgic, "velvet" voice was well-suited for his mournful songs, haunted by his unrequited love for an Indian princess he met during his grand tour of Asia in the 1930s. His most famous such song, \'\'Mavi Kelebek\'\' ("Blue Butterfly"), won him a legion of female fans.<ref name=Turkey/> \xc3\x96zg\xc3\xbcr was the first male tango singer to rise to prominence in Turkey, where the tango tradition had been dominated by women.<ref>From the inside cover of \xc3\x96zg\xc3\xbcr\'s \'\'[http://www.oliversudden.com/EasternEurope/Ibrahimozgur/Tangolar.html Tangolar]\'\' CD, Label Oriente Music. Reproduced online at oliversudden.com, URL accessed 13 July 2006.</ref>

==P==

*[[H\xc3\xa9ctor Pacheco]]{{Ref_label|tango.info|TI|none}} {{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}
*[[Carlos Paiva]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t\t
*[[H\xc3\xa9ctor Palacios]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t\t
*[[Anita Palmero]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t\t
*[[Jerzy Petersburski]]
*[[\xc3\x81stor Piazzolla]](March 11, 1921 \xe2\x80\x93 July 4, 1992) His oeuvre revolutionized the traditional tango into a new style termed nuevo tango, incorporating elements from jazz and classical music. He is known in his native land as "El Gran \xc3\x81stor" ("The Great Astor").
*[[Alberto Podest\xc3\xa1]]{{Ref_label|tango.info|TI|none}} {{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t

*[[Susana Rinaldi]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}} {{flagicon|Argentina}} (1935-), known as "la passionaria du tango",<ref>UNESCO, \'\'[http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=9923&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html Biography of Susana Rinaldi]\'\', unesco.org. URL accessed 13 July 2006</ref> is also an actress. To avoid military rule, she settled in [[France]] where she has enjoyed a successful career.<ref>Julio Nudler, \'\'[http://www.todotango.com/english/creadores/srinaldi.html Susana Rinaldi]\'\'. todotango.com. URL accessed 12 July 2006</ref> A [[UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador]] and social justice campaigner, she has been active in the artists\' rights movement.<ref>UNESCO, \'\'[http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=8326&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html Susana Rinaldi]\'\', unesco.org. URL accessed 13 July 2006</ref>

*[[Diego Sol\xc3\xads]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}}\t\t
*[[Julio Sosa]]{{Ref_label|tango.info|TI|none}} {{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}} {{flagicon|Uruguay}} (1926-1964) from [[Uruguay]] was one of the most important tango singers during tango\'s unhappy years in the 1950s and early 1960s. His passion for poetry led to his sole published book; his passion for fast cars led to his young death.<ref>Roberto Selles. \'\'[http://www.todotango.com/english/creadores/jsosa.html Julio Sosa]\'\'. todotango.com. URL accessed 12 July 2006</ref>
*[[Hrysoula Stefanaki]]{{Ref_label|todotango|TT|none}} {{flagicon|Greece}} popular Greek singer / vocalist, and musician, born in Heraklion, Crete, Greece, best known for her outstanding & unique performances on national & international retro songs such as \xe2\x80\x9cTango Noturno\xe2\x80\x9d, \xe2\x80\x9cBlue Haven\xe2\x80\x9d, \xe2\x80\x9cThe last waltz\xe2\x80\x9d, \xe2\x80\x9cRegretting for wasted years\xe2\x80\x9detc.

 ****** List of UK garage artists

b'{{unreferenced|date=September 2012}}
This is a list of notable artists who have worked in the [[UK garage]] genre and subgenres, except [[dubstep]] and [[Grime (music)|grime]] as they have their own lists. This includes notable artists who have either been very important to the genre or have had a considerable amount of exposure (such as in the case of one that has been on a major label, but not limited to such). This list does not include little-known local artists. Only artists who have articles are included. Groups and artists with aliases are listed by the first letter in their name (not including the words "a", "an", "DJ" or "the"), and individuals are listed by their surname.
